text: Aus der Flasche auf der Berliner Biermeile 2013 getrunken. Ui ui ui! Verrücktes Bier für verrückte Leurte, so heißt wohl der Wahlspruch von Sam Calagiones Leute und hier trift das voll zu. Kardamon, Koriander, Wachholderbeeren, Schwarze Tee werden mit heißen Flußsteinen in den Gärbottichen geworfen und ergeben ein eher süßliches, fast schon ein Weihnachtsbier. Spannend und komplex! Bei sommerlichen Temperaturen von 35°C schon etwas zu komplex!

Bottle courtesy of TATTORSO. Thanks Jeff!

A light hazy orange golden colour, it gives about an inch of foam and has some nice sticky lacing.

Ok, the smell really is different. Im getting some spice like cinnamon and nutmeg, grain and what must be the Chai that they speak of, juniper...weird smelling and Im not sure how to react. If this nose is to the style, I cant knock it. Actually, the more whiffs I take, the more it grows on me. 

The taste is honey sweet with a graininess, chai(?), strong spiciness(see smell), some banana flavour....as weird a taste as the smell. 

Medium bodied with medium carbonation. Plenty of warming is now sneaking up on me.

Drinkability? Im totally mixed in my feelings about the smell and taste but one thing is clear to me. This is a unique brew and in its uniqueness, I cant see myself having this one again but I thank Jeff for giving me a chance to try it.

2014 bottle. Murky orange with an average off white head that shrinks quickly. Aroma is black tea, honey, juniper, spruce, and mixed herbs. Taste is full of tea, with juniper, grains, and herbs. Floral and dry on the finish with an average thickness.

Multiple bottles in 2010, Shared this one with Pat, pours hazy orange with a thicker sized foam. Smell and taste are lemon lime juniper, cinnamon, german malt, cardamom, all spice, and other dark earthy notes. Probably over spiced even for the ingredients but Ive always liked Indian profiles especially Hashish.

Pours a clear amber color. Aromas of pine/malts and a touch of citrus/berries. Flavor is a little different. I thought it would be more pine tasting. A little berry flavor and some hop bitterness near the end.

Hazy golden color; Medium creamy body; Aroma of malt/wheat, yeast, juniper, coriander, & citrus; Flavor of sweet malt/wheat, coriander, caramel, citrus, some honey, and spice; Nice herbal tea qualities - interesting brew.

Bottle - good size foamy head, hazy burnt orange color with lots of "floaties" (maybe bad poor?), big fruity/berry aroma and flavor, moderate spice (from the tea I guess), a little different but in a good way overall 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Clear Amber color. $12.99/750ml is pricey versus alternatives in this market. Just not true to original style.

Bottle sample at a tasting. Thanks Yoav. Hazy yellow with lots of sediments. Smell of cardamom, lavender, herbs, clove. Sweet, spicy, green tea,cardamom, coriander, herbal bitterness, over-spiced and not balanced . Light-medium bodied.
This beer is great for relaxing on a cold day. Amazing flavor, sums up Autumn in a bottle

Bottle. Pours slightly hazy gold. Aroma is heavy black and chai tea, floral notes, orange peel, and faint toast. Flavor is sweet with mostly chai flavors along with some faint black tea, toasted malts, and some mixed spice. Medium body.

Bottle sample at Vovas Hoppy Beerthday tasting at Dancing Camel Florentin, Tel Aviv. Thanks Yoav. Golden with small off-white head and lots of particles. Aroma of lavender, herbal tea, chamomile, very floral. Sweet flavor with notes of lavender, tea, chamomile and clove, spicy, bitterish, medicinal and alcoholic. Medium-bodied.

Bottle sample at Vovas Hoppy Beerthday tasting at Dancing Camel Florentin. Thanks Yoav. Golden with floaties. Huge cardamom and clove aroma, with other spices and some fruitiness. Sweet flavor with malt, caramel, cardmamom, clove, some fruitiness, a tart hint. Medium-bodied. Not my thing.

No head, only a smattering of fine bubbles. No lace either. Cloudy orange-amber color.

Lots of Caribbean style spice to the nose: all spice, nutmeg, clove, coriander and cinnamon. Theres a pepper aspect to the smell.

Less beer and more a spicy soft drink without sugar. Very high carbonation for the level of body. Lots of clove and pepper in the swallow.

I love Dogfishs willingness to try something wild, different and bizarre. And their willingness to put it in front of the general public. I hope they never stop doing this. Sometimes they get hits, sometimes misses. For me, this is one of their greatest misses.

Big bottle, thanks to madmitch76, shared at my local bottle share, 7th July 2015. 

Golden appearance which is orange in colour. Aroma is Japanese black tea and coriander and clove. Some banana and clove flavours are prominent too. Wit beer yeast? Interesting ale.

Pours burnt orange with a small soapy white head. Aroma is earthy, citrus, coriander, tea and spices...alot going on and it really opens up as it warms. Taste is mild all around, with well balanced bittersweetness. Medium bodied, softly carbonation, smooth mouth feel and enjoyable. Alcohol is well hidden.
Pours a nice copper to brownish color. big frothy head thats stays for a long time. Smell like tea, very malty and with a Suttle feel as a Weis. The Chai and berries gives it a nice touch.
Great flavor with a chai tea kick that brings the flavor with a smooth bang. One of the best Dogfish Head beers yet.

Tasted on 1/3/12 from a capped 750mL bottle. Pours hazy brassy golden with an average white head that leaves thin lacing. The nose is dominated by chai tea, with caramel malt and some cardamom spice. The flavor is quite sweet with tons of caramel and chai with some herbal bitterness. The body is medium and oily with light carbonation and a long caramel chai finish.
Its strong, spicy, floral, sweet, kind of malty, with hints of tea. It is a good fermented beverage, just not my style, too spicy and fenolic.

"9% abv (not 6) so there is a kick. hazy tan-orange color. aroma is wonderful*. its been chilly here for the last few days and this would fit perfect as a late fall or winter seasonal. one taster said it smells like Christmas. The * is that wonderful in this sense is a well blended chai tea. if youre a sucker for chai tea like me, youll love this beer. if not, theres really no reason to drink a chai tea beer! body is full and feel is pretty smooth. flavor is great...black tea, spices, juniper, malt, yeast. very very good with a lasting impression. i wish this were more easily available."

Bottle:
Cloudy, tallow-gold with a small, white head.
Nutmeg, chai-tea aroma.
Sweet, honey, nutmeg, fruit syrup, banana.
Very tasty and unusual....excellent.
Bottle. Nutmeg, honey, chai, and light juniper aroma. Hazy golden yellow with small head. Sweet honey, banana, nutmeg and chai tea flavor. Very tasty.
Pours deep copper, very little head, slightly hazy. Smells of juniper, tea, caramel, clove. Tastes of tea, juniper, various spices. Medium malt body
Pours a light amber with a white foam head. Aroma is chai tea and berries. Flavor is the same, sweet, with a smooth, creamy mouthfeel. Very easy to drink and delicious.

Not my normal beer. Great change of pace. Perfect flavor aroma texture, etc. don't need to have again any time soon but nice chai tea flavored ale.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle from total wine in fl. Hard to find a complaint. Beautiful aroma- spice.. cloves. Amazing flavor- vanilla chai. So easy to drink. One of my new favorites

Really good stuff, but you cant call it "subtle and balanced." Turns out, I like not subtle and unbalanced. You get a big dose of spiced tea, then hints of lemon, spicy rye, and finally banana esters. Very unbeerlike. The alcohol content, 9%, is definitely subtle. Happy I cant taste the ramps.
Cloves and bananas in this pale orangeish hazy brew with a small white head of tiny bubbles. I get a spicy flavor much like the aroma with a christmas flavor a medium body and decent carb.

Bottle (750ml): pours cloudy golden. Smells spicy. Wow this is different. Not bad but different. Spices are very strong, cinnamon and tea? not sure what juniper berries taste like. Not bad but too many others that I would rather drink

750mL bottle. Pours a pale golden, slight haze, big fluffy white head with killer retention and lacing. Nose is lots of spice (the chai blend come sthrough clearly with the cardamom, cloves and coriander) some banana, grass, daffodils. Mouth is medium bodied, medium sweet, rye coming through, a lot of the flavors that are in the aroma -- spices, florals, grasses, yada, yada, yada. The only disappointment is that Im not getting the juniper berries -- which is what I was most looking forward to -- and I imagine it might be overpowered by the spices added in. Regardless, this is a very tasty beverage and would be exceptionally good during the late fall when the air gets chilly and damp here in Chicago.

750ml bottle purchased at Knightly Spirits in Orlando, Florida. Golden yellow, thin dissipating white head, very light patchy lacing. Aroma is of spice, some pepper, very floral with lots of perfume. Flavour is of perfume, spices and pepper, starfruit. Floral mouthfeel, medium/light body, moderate carbonation. Finishes long with some spice and flowers.
 Another in the long line of interesting and little known styles from Dogfish. Im glad they have the balls to do something like this.
Smell of ginger and spice. Appearance is golden yellow with off white head. Taste is sweet banana with clove spice and ginger.

Bomber from Supermarket Liquors. Appearance: two fingers white head, does not last too long, cloudy orange color, no lacing. Aroma: cinnamon, ginger, other spices, caramel, light chai. As beer warms up, chai is much more apparent and ginger dissipates. Palate: medium body, average to lively carbonation, oily texture, light spice finish. Taste: sweet caramel, into light Belgian yeastiness, then the spices come out; primarily cinnamon and a bit of ginger, these last until it eventually peters out. As beer warms, chai taste takes over and prevails. Overall, super very different and unique, drinkable, alcohol is hidden well, and well balanced. Very enjoyable.
Pours a deep golden with white head. Floral, herbal, tea, and spice on the nose; follows onto the palate. Finishes sweet.

Bottle from Mane Liquor. Pours clear orange with a tiny white rim around the edge. As Jackson pointed out, the nose is very close to banana bread. Broken down it has loads of spices - cinnamon and clove driven with HEAPS of banana, toffee, walnut and tea leaves. Kind of has similarities to banana and butterscotch with a lemon zest kick to it. Taste is rum n raisin like with heavy banana esters and cinnamon before the dark and tangy fruits finish it off, especially lemon grass. Has a very sticky sweet end to it like raisins, cloves, cardamom and cinnamon sticks. Quite earthy towards the finish as well. On the sweet side of things and quite decadent. Carbonation is soft. A very well put together beer

Bottle from Mane Liquor. Immediate aroma of banana bread, cinammon, juniper, ginger and tea leaves. The banana note is very stong. Light toasted caramel malts mixed in with lots of herbs and spices across the palate. Similarly, banana lollies and ginger are quite present. Maybe a touch too sweet for me. A sweet peppery fruit finish. Very soft carbonation. Cool beer!
Tap at Lazy Dog. Pours a hazy muddy golden with a nice layer of cream colored. Taste of lemons and malts. Aroma of spice and fruit.

750 ml bottle into signature tulip glass, bottled on 3/11/2013. Pours fairly hazy/cloudy deep gold color with a 1-2 finger dense white head with good retention, that reduces to a small cap that lingers. Spotty soapy lacing clings around the glass, with a good amount of streaming carbonation retaining the head. Aromas of big juniper, black tea, cinnamon, cardamom, clove, ginger, black pepper, herbal, grass, light banana, light caramel, bread, and herbal/yeast earthiness. Fantastic aromas with awesome balance and complexity of fruity/earthy yeast, spices, and bready malt sweetness; with great strength. Taste of big juniper, black tea, cinnamon, cardamom, ginger, clove, herbal, light banana, black pepper, grass, light caramel, bread, and herbal/yeast earthiness. No bitterness on the finish; with lingering notes of juniper, black tea, cinnamon, cardamom, ginger, clove, light banana, herbal, grass, light caramel, bread, and yeast earthiness on the finish for a while. Fantastic complexity and balance of fruity/earthy yeast, spices, and bready malt sweetnesss; with an awesome malt/spice balance and zero cloying flavors after the finish. Medium carbonation and medium-full bodied; with a very smooth and fairly creamy/slick mouthfeel that is nice. Alcohol is well hidden with only a light warming present after the finish. Overall this is a fantastic Sahti style. All around awesome complexity and balance of fruity/earthy yeast, spices, and bready malt sweetness; and extremely smooth to sip on for the ABV. A highly enjoyable offering.
caramel, herbs, citrus, spruce, clove, BUY AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE WHEN YOU FIND IT, YOU FOOL

Transfer from BA review from 7-2-12 - 
Served on tap in a 10 oz chalice glass

Appearance  Pours a hazy golden color with a light white head. The head fades quickly leave a light amount of lacing.

Smell  The smell is fruity and spicy. Aromas of citrus and berry are a nice base with which aromas of some juniper spice and a light pine aroma rest upon. Mixed with these are smells of yeast and some light breadiness as well. 

Taste  The taste starts out on the fruitier and sweet side with a good dose of citrus and some berry flavors. These are mixed with juniper and some yeast tastes. The juniper soon becomes more potent with other spices of nutmeg and cinnamon coming to the tongue as well. As the taste advances further a herbal tea flavor comes to the tongue and takes the taste to the end where some floral flavors mix in with the herbal tea to leave a very interesting flavor on the tongue.

Mouthfeel  The body of the beer was on the medium side with the carbonation level just a hint above average. The average body was good for the tea, spice and fruit flavors with the carbonation level making it more refreshing then a standard 9 % abv brew.

Overall  It was an interesting and tasty brew. One to try if you get a chance.

75 cL bottle bit by bit into a pint into a pint glass. Clear orange with plenty of gas. Nice bubbly head but it doesnt hang around. Coriander spiced aroma, a hint of menthol - very unusual but impressive. Crisp, light menthol spice, yet smooth with a light bitter finish. A sound an unusual tipple.

Almost bready aroma with thin creamy head. Medium body reminiscent of a Belgian ale. Does not taste like a high ETOH brew (9%). 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Very good weizen. Pour is not great... No head and lightly cloudy. Flavor is wheat and yeast.
Golden amber color and spicy sweet flavor. Wonderfully fruity and spicy flavor with no bitter

I had this at Global Brew. Pours deep gold with white head. Taste coriander, wheat, a little like a Hefeweizen. I thought this was pretty good. I would definitely drink this again.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Great beer. Pours like a weizen. Has complex aromas including caramel, corriender and some very obvious tea. The beer itself is very light on the pallet, has a strong finish and the tea is more for smell than the taste. 8/10

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Light orange poured from a bottle with moderate head. Scent of tea as in the name with a sweet tea aftertaste

Bottle from unknown, via Jasmine. Pours a bright orange, clear with little to no head. Aroma sweet and full in chai, very earthy. Body full with a slight liveliness, some syrupy character from ABV. Finish well rounded and subtle.
Catching up on some old ratings from Untappd -- First rated on 1 Oct 2011. Very similar to a triple but with tea.

Rated on 7-11-2010. This beer pours a small smooth head with a lengthy retention, opaque body, fast rising carbonation and no lacing. The aroma is yeasty, earthy and spicy. The taste is sweet, rye, spicy, some yeast, and the ABV comes through. The palate is tingly and this beer is medium bodied. Overall this beer has a nice spice characteristic to it in the aroma and flavor. The ABV does come through in the flavor, but it is not overpowering. This beer is worth trying.
From bottle at Royal Oak Craft Beer Fest. Golden pour. Nose of tea leaves. Mild yeastiness paired with predominant flavors of tea and spices. Good, slightly more of a novelty.
Bomber from Imbibe Wine. Nose is spicy cinnamon and cloves with iced tea. Hazy pale yellow with a miniscule white head. Flavor is very spicy cinnamon and cloves.

Hats off to Dogfish. This one works. If you don't drink tea, you need not to apply. This one is tea-tea-tea all the way through. And it's good. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Thanks to Hopswagger for this one!
750ml bottle served in a Duvel tulip
Bottled in 2010

A - Burnt orange color with a tight knit head. The head sinks into a collar while finally vanishing.

S - Lactic sourness and lavender salts are the first thing that jumps out. Smells like this will be quite tart. Dried plantains, strawberries, peach, apricots, spicy, ginger, pepper, nutmeg, lavender, rye bread, heavy dose of cardamon. Salty savory and sweet biscuit/bread malts.

T - Peach, apricot, and plantain puree, a soft lactic tartness is there but not as pronounced as the nose described. Lemons, pepper, cardamon, nutmeg, honey, ginger, salty, you can really taste the chai in there. Very yeasty with sweet and indulgent and earthy pale malts. A steady herbal note right through the middle, woody, Im guessing the juniper? Finishes with a fruity tartness and notes of salt, spice, and mint left on the aftertaste.

M - Hefty body makes for a thick feel, semi-dry finish.

The aroma is bigtime! Acidic fruit, spices, sweet and savory, very aromatic. The flavor follows but doesnt quite live up to the aroma.Very good mix of sweet and salty flavors. Big malt presence with lively yeast esters. Various spices that show up at different times. This would obviously pair excellent with Indian food or other curry dishes.

Serving type: bottle

06-29-2013

I had this in a mug due to Sahti recommendations. The appearance was a nice light yet hazy golden yellow/amber colored looking body with a one finger white foamy head that dies into the body within about thirty seconds. No lacing whatsoever. The aroma has one of the best parts of this beer and I absolutely love this (unsure how close this is truly to its style), but I get some juniper berries coming through in a earthy sort of way and I do get the cardamom, cinnamon, ginger, cloves and black pepper all coming through in a super nice way. The taste is spicy sweet through the previously mentioned flavors, I have to admit I do get the German yeastiness in the taste though I didnt notice it in the smell - still good; sticky sweet yet somewhat spicy aftertaste; dry sweet yet spicy finish. On the palate, she sits about a light to medium, ABV really isnt noticed, sessionable - hmmm...maybe slightly, carbonation is really smooth - I like it, but my lack of having "sahtis" doesnt say enough for me to tell you how good this is for its style, sorry, Ill try to find more as I can. Overall, what an awesome brew I got in a trade, holy moley, well done Dogfish Head and will definitely look for this again.
Limited notes from time of drinking. Remember liking this one a good bit though. One of the first dogfish traditional ales i tried.

Bottle split between three people... never heard of this beer or style before, so I was excited to try it out. Poured into a Dixie cup at a party.

Appearance: Red cup, so I couldnt see it too well, but a murky sort of brown color with a lot of yeasty tea-leaf sediment. Kind of ugly by most peoples standards, I reckon.

Smell: Tea. A tang/sourness. Cinnamon? Some sort of spiciness. Berries.

Taste/feel: Tea with a tangy Belgian characteristic. Berries. Somebody mentioned cinnamon, and I got that as well. Not bitter in the slightest. Sort of refreshing, but at the same time, theres a slight warmth of alcohol. Interesting, tasty beer. I believe it was $12 for the bottle, which isnt too bad at all for such a unique tasting brew. Its not for everybody -- it has a good bit of "funk" to it in the taste and aroma, but I enjoyed it quite a lot. Worth a pick up.

clear thin dark yellow body. white frothy head. good lacing. mostly diminishing. aroma: pumpkin coconut candy, dried banana, clove, juniper. if and ff: heavy sweet. palate: medium full body, lively carbonation, oily texture, metallic finish. 40s

On tap @ Blind Tiger House. They would probably get an diploma if they could fill this glass any fuller, and the beer itself is a deep blurry dark honey colored thing with no head what so ever. It has lots if aroma this! Ginger is the main thing that hits the nose, lavender is the second thing that comes to mind. Smells really herbal with cold unsweetened tea and infused fresh basil. Really interesting aroma on this, and the flavor is just as interesting. Lots of herbal ginger, heather honey, spices, cloves, banana and tea. Its like a heffe on steroids! Good oily mouthfeel and a average small prickling carbonation level. At first I thought this would be to much, call it overkill but it actually turned out to be a really good beer this. Extreme and really different. 16.06.2013
A bit all over the place flavor. An interesting fruity semi sweet beer. Yet another good interesting beer. And they used tea which is awesome by itself.

Dark yellow with some suspended matter and a small pale head. Aroma is juniper berries, chai spices. Slightly slick mouthfeel, sweet on the palate. Flavour is chai spices, candi sugar, hint of juniper.
On tap at Alewife Baltimore. Pours star with a thin white head. Aroma of spice cardamom cinnamon. Yuck. Tastes like cheap perfume. Don't like this at all. Floral. Thin bodied.

10/16/2010. 750 ml. bottle. Another unique DFH concoction. Cloudy golden color with a white head. Aromas are spicy with light fruit and yeast showing well. Full bodies with spices, tea and fruit. Interesting.
Complex aroma of herbs and wheat malt. Hazy golden, white ring head. Tastes of corriander, lemongrass, cardamon, licorice. Very smooth. Pretty refreshing.

750 thanks to Jordan! Great to see you man. Pours a clear golden color with a medium white head. A big tea-like aroma with some fruit. The flavor is interesting: tea, apricot, phenolic banana esters, the yeast comes in big. Sharp flavors overall. Light heat. Nice.

You can smell this beer from the other side if the bar. It has a great combination of spices making it truly unique. The mouth has a spicy and almost fruity flavor with a clean crisp finish similar to a hefe. Great unique beer for the right occasion.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

October 26, 2013 - bottle shared by someone at Darkness Day. Golden orange pour with some head. Aroma and taste that was sweet and spicy. There was a lot of other really good stuff on the table, so this wasnt getting any love, but it was solid.

Nose is all black tea and cardomom. Pour is a dull reddish straw mildly hazy.

Strong wheat with extra alcohol on the palate, smoothly effervescent but a bit too mildly so.

Really interesting and tasty enough, just not really balanced

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Orange yellow with small foam ring. Aroma is gloves for sure. Taste is spicy gloves, little bittersweet. Aftertaste short lasting. (Houston 201310)

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Appearance: Clear medium amber with finger thick white head.
Aroma: Cinnamon, clove, aniseed, biscuit, fruity, floral, bubble gum and tea.
Taste: Medium sweetness and bitterness with low sourness. Slightly salty.
Palate: Thick rough texture, medium body, average carbonation, lingering spicy finish and a touch astringent.
Comments: Enjoyable as a one off. Too much spice and a bit sickly.

22 Fl. Oz. Bottle. Poured clear, golden in color with a nice white head and lots of lacing on the glass. Aroma of spices (some clove maybe), fruits combined with some malts and other herbal, earthy notes. Taste is quite complex and interesting mild sweetness and a some fruit combined with a nice bitterness and some tea notes too. Quite weird but some how it works; very good beer.
Draft. Hazy orange pour with a thin white head that laces. Nose is chai, nutmeg, spices. Taste is similar. Smooth mouth feel.

Nice range of tastes from gentle "blonde" ale to some moderate spices (the Juniper berries, the Black Chai Tea?) and a nice sweetness (from the malt, some other source?). This is my first Sahti so I have nothing to compare it to directly (within the style) but I point to other styles that I know for some comparison. I think that it might be closest to a Belgian blonde (maybe a Leffe?) but that it is maltier and with more of a spice profile. Excellent taste.
Pours a dark golden. Delicious taste with just enough of the tea flavor coming through.

Pours golden in colour, clear with a frothy white head. Aroma is of juniper, herbs and spice with a noticeable chai tea character. Taste is a mild sweetness throughout with a nice balanced bitterness. Thin on the palate, light-medium body, and lively carbonation. Overall an awesome and unique beer.

Tap. Pours a clear orangish body with a small wispy white head that retained as a thin film. The nose is really interesting and complex, lots of spice and herbal notes, the tea comes across strongest. A little bit of yeastiness and lemongrass. The flavor, despite being such a mash up of ingredients is still rather light and delicate with a lot of complexity. Tea, spice, Hefe yeast, some bubblegum notes on the finish, even a touch of smoke. Lingering herbal finish. Light bodied, fizzy carbonation, very easy drinking, cant tell that this is 9% at all. I was really surprised by this one, this is one of the better DFH crazy beers.
On tap at Shortys. What a strange and delicious beer! Very complex flavor and aroma.

Bottle at BBF2013 shared with a few other punters. A strange one this. Aroma is berry & tea. Flavour is a mix of fruit, spice, tea, a little sweet in general. Finish is zesty herb. Strange mix but it kinda works.

On tap at the Dogfish Head Brewery in Milton. Light gold color w/ no head; the nose was strongly of cloves, almost reminiscent of a whiskey-ish scent. Taste, however, was overly sweet, somewhat cloying. The inclusion of cloves, juniper, and chai tea are prevalent.

Draft at Shortys. Taste is drinkable with a mildly boozy aftertaste. Complex and easy drinking. I lime this cause I can't figure out what it's like

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle. Pours hazy golden with an off white head. Aroma of malt, cinnamon, some fruitiness, some berries and toffee. Flavor is sweet work some malty notes, cinnamon, Chai and citrus. Medium body, average carbonation.

Bottle, 75cl. A hazy dark golden beer with a dense, off-white head leaving lacings. Honey, herbs, heather and juniper on the nose, none extreme in any way. Some alcohol too. The flavor is a bit sweet, with honey, bitterness, herbs and a spice hint. Heather too. Full body, a tad warming, and pleasantly carbonated. Lasting finish. Decent indeed, and not too honey-ish like honey beers tend to be. A bit warming though. 130810

Hazy amber pour with a white head. Aromas of juniper berries, lemon, and chai. Very complex aromas and the flavor follows suit completely. Inital flavor of malty goodness with the juniper berries and chai tea coming through. Just a pinch of corriander and lemon in the finish. Sweet, smooth finish. Very drinkable. This was a truly great beer, very interesting and unique.

Pours cloudy orange with a small white head. Large visible sediments in the beer that may seem off putting but do not have any effect on the taste or mouthfeel.

Smells-Spicy and sweet. Cinnamon and chai are definitely present with some hints of clove or anise.

Tastes- Sweet and pleasant. Cinnamon and chai dominate but there is a hint of black licorice that is very pleasant. 

Mouthfeel- Thick full body.

Overall-Nice sweet/spiced beer. I will definitely try again.

Pours a opaque bright orange with quickly settling bright white head, minimal lacing. Aroma is strong chai and berry, herbal, sweet, fruity, juicy, alcohol and mild spice. Flavor is strong fruit, berry, chai, herbal, mildly vegetal, pumpkin, spice, quite sweet, mildly sweet, slight alcohol finish and chai aftertaste. Soft to moderate carbonation, juicy and sticky texture, and a mildly warm finish. Interesting, very sweet, fairly enjoyable, unique.
Kudos to DFH for trying, but Im not a fan of this. Its too sweet, and too spiced. Nice hefe influence, though.

As I walk into the forrest, rich with juniper, I breathe deeply of the earth, wet, pungent, sweet...with that harsh balance of nature and ancient history. I awake from this vision holding a beer whose aroma has taken me someplace so temporally remote...another sip...donning amber, it tastes of pepper and chai tea, cardamom and grass. The finish is nearly sweet and leaves me feeling adventurous...ready to explore the rest of the vast wilderness of yore!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Cloudy amber hue like runny local honey. Little to no head - although a constant onslaught of rising bubbles did their best to remedy this throughout the tasting. Aroma is very unique and complex. Cloves, cardamom and coriander prevail. Overall, this is a pretty good proto-beer, as they call it, but I would argue their claims of elevated quaffability like a desperate, crooked lawyer needing to win his first case. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

A clowdy amber in color smells of spices cinnamon and chai. Palate is refreshed but left with the spice as an after taste. I am not a fan of chai and cardamom in the long run the novelty wore off and a was left with spices that arent my favorite flavors.
UPDATED: JUL 18, 2013 Bottled. This beer pours yellow with no head or lace. Smell of gin and black tea. Taste chai, almost like a saison, starts strong and end mild.

Cloudy, pale with a hint red with a thick white head. Aroma is spiced, like chai tea with hints of vanilla. Flavor is once again much like a chai tea with some malt present. Very interesting, refreshing in an interesting way but very flavorful.

Wife: 4.39

Strong aroma of sage, lemon zest and citrus. Copper appearance with strong foam. Intense herb overtones including sage, saffron and lemon grass. Undertones of orange peel, chai tea and biscuit. Overall, very pleasing and very fresh. Reminds me of a homebrew I made

March 28th, 2010 - A Finnish proto-beer! And the recipe for this brew looks like a witchs potion! I wonder if Ill even have the sensory capacity to parse this brew out, but I barrel ahead, eager to dip into Dogfish Heads latest adventuresome brew. The body is a slightly hazy pumpkin orange color, blossoming with a thick, almost golden ahead. It also smells like a pumpkin seasonal beer. Of all the spices listed in the commercial description, it is easiest to pick out the smell of chai tea. That must be the cardamom, coriander and Indian black tea talking (is that 9th century Finnish?), but this beer is already taking on a sub-continent flavor that I find fascinating and mildly Orientalist in thinking. The flavor is sweet on the palate, offering the chai tea and spices with moderate sugars, apparently from the hot rock caramelization, which pair expertly with all the exotic ingredients packed into the beer. Of all of the daring and bold Dogfish Head beers, this one might be my favorite. Its distant and unfamiliar enough to capture my attention, but sufficiently beer like that Im not repulsed when I drink it.

Dogfish Head SAHTEA:
Ale brewed with Black Chai Tea and Juniper Berries

My Opinion:
A golden/orange, chai tea color is the first thing that will catch your eye as you pour out this delicious and intriguing ale. The next thing that will highten your scences is the delightful aroma that parades out of the bottle ever so gracefully. The cozy smell of chai tea captures the fall season perfectly, leaving you imagining bright colered leaves slowly changing in the cool breeze. The taste... Smooth. A gentle sweetness greets the tongue as the taste of piney juniper berries quickly follow. This ale says its goodbyes with the delicious taste of the chai, leaving a creamy semi-dry mouthfeel that wraps all these intresting flavors togethor into an ale that im sure dogfish head proudly calls Sahtea!

(9% alc. by vol.) (Light and Smooth)

Ive decided that Im not a fan of Sahtea in general. Have had one from Sam Adams as well and Im just not a huge fan. DFH is very complex, slightly spicy and it just wasnt for me. Yes, there were a lot "floaties" that came from the bottom of the bottle when poured.

6/16 1:40 Aroma is complex and jumps at you.  Appearance is light and clear.  Taste is so many tastes up front with a spicy finish.  There might be too much going on for some people, but I really enjoy it.

Pours a murky yellow-gold on tap with decent white head but little lacing. Aroma is german yeast, but then youre blasted with the spices. Taste is all the spices, kind of like chai, coriander and slight cinnamon. One of the better dogfish side projects.
Has a bit of a juniper taste, but leans more toward coriander.  Overall decent, reminds me of a pumpkin beer.

Pour out of 750 mL bottle, thanks to Aaron for the pour! Hazy yellow with lots of yeast in suspension, aroma has notes of coriander, biscuit, bread, lemon, hints of tea, some leafy notes, slight caramel notes, smells nice!  Taste is sweet biscuit, nice tea, coriander, biscuit, bread, some nice yeast notes, some slight lemon, hints of vanilla, finishing fairly sweet but bitter.

Bottle @ Dans house. Holy shit, theres a ton of shit in suspension. Yellowish orange appearance with a small white head with TONS of floaties. Herbal tea, juniper, sprucey, herbal, somewhat citrusy, fairly spicy aroma. Banana, lemon citrusy, spicy yeast, juniper, herbal tea flavor. Cool idea to use a weizen yeast. Quite interesting.

One again THE LOCAL BEER BAR in Eureka, CA brings us an unusual and quite tasty beer. This draft pour came a hazy golden color with a foamy white head and good lacing. The aroma is complex, with juniper and a lot of heat.  Medium to full in body, the mouthfeel is lively and a bit alcoholic The flavor keep showing you something new, with fruit, juniper, and flowers.  The finish is tantalizing with lots of spices, including allspice, nutmeg, and clove, and then brings on lemon-grass.  This is a remarkable beer and after you get past the juniper is a pagan beer dance on the senses. Love this stuff.
On draft.  Spicy fun and great.  Juniper berries, spices galore.  I love this beer.  Cheers!
This was sweet, complex, spicy and delicious. Tastes of ginger, tea, and juniper berries, leading to a dry spicy finish.

Pours a cloudy golden yellow colour with a little white lacing. Aroma of hay, Belgium yeast, black pepper, and tea. It tastes just like it smells. This is a nice beer, very different, very complex. A nice Belgium

Tap flight at Bavarian Lodge.  Hazy golden pour with a foamy, filmy, bright white head.  The head leaves a thin blanket on the glass.  Aroma of spices.  A figurative spice rack in the glass.  Taste is spicy with nutmeg, allspice, lemongrass, cardamom, cinnamon, and clove.  Pretty clean finish makes this quite drinkable and leaves you wanting another sip.  German Purity Law honks will hate this.  The rest of us will enjoy heat they dont drink.

Aroma- cinnamon, chai tea, spices
Appearance- flat hazy yellow, no real head
Taste- unlike anything that Ive ever had, spiciness, many herbs, berries, citrus, tea
Palate- medium-bodied, crisp and clean
Overall- I loved it the first time I had it a few years ago.  Nowadays, while its still pretty good, it doesnt blow me away.  Very unique and always welcomed, but not incredible.

A - Pours a hazy golden orange with a finger of frothy white head atop. The head fades down at a normal pace leaving behind some light lacing.

S - Aroma is a mix of juniper, coriander and other spices, a bit of citrus, some sweet bready malts, some fruity yeast character, tea, and a bit of floral aromas.

T - Starts off with some coriander, cinnamon, and other spices, some fruity yeast character, juniper beers, and a touch of citrus. Through the middle, some sweet bready malts come through with some stronger fruity esters, some tea flavor, and some floral elements. The finish is a mix of sweet bready malts, fruity esters with a hint of dark fruit, juniper and other spices, and some tea.

M - Medium bodied with moderate carbonation. Feels smooth with a sweet and estery finish.

D - Very drinkable. Lots of interesting aromas and flavors mixed in, but the overall beer comes together quite nicely. I like the juniper especially.

Bottle at Scopeys Pre-CBC tune-up. The pour is hazy golden with a tiny eggshell white head. Theres loads of yeast in the bottle. The nose is of apricot syrup, sweet pears and honey. The taste is wild and unfamiliar. I get acerbic sweet green fruits, some banana and golden pear. Theres notes of cat piss and sour moldy grapes on the finish. Theres a spicy ginger character to this beer too, some juniper. The bodys light and tangy, yeasty. Overall, it was quite an interesting beer. I cant say that Id want to drink more than a few ounces of it, but I was quite happy to try it.
Enjoyed with Kaeti and Correl at Beer Revolution. Awesome holiday spice, makes me want to be home for the holidays. Love this.

On tap at Octane Coffee. Pours a slightly hazy yellow with a dash of orange hue. About a finger of white head that dissipates soon after initial smell and sip. Aroma is very potent and inviting, reminiscent of a strong spiced cider almost. I assume much of the spicy aroma can be attributed to the perfect blend of juniper berries and chai tea. Flavor is surprisingly crisp for how much flavor this beer actually brings. At 9%, this is a very satisfying and drinkable beer so look out.

Bottle at my Pre-CBC Tune-Up Tasting, thanks to jackl. It pours light orange, with a thin white head. The nose orange, tea, peppery juniper, very aromatic, herbal and something akin to urinal cake. The taste is orange, mango, tangerine, herbal, floral, jasmine, tangy, tea and ginger, with a dry, slightly citric finish. Medium body and moderate carbonation. Very interesting indeed.
Pours a hazy amber with the barest of heads.  Smells of spices, tea, rye bread, clove, banana, bubblegum.  Taste is medium sour, lightly sweet - notes of spices, a sour berry flavor.

Refrigerated bottle poured into a shaker.  Pours tranlucent deep golden with big suspended chucks and dull white head that dissapates quckly.  Very little lacing, thick body, and tea and coriander aroma.  Taste is sweet malt, cardamom, some tea, hint of lemon, and finishes long cardamom.  Not that hard to drink for the abv, and increasing warming alcohol as it comes to room temperature.

UPDATED: APR 28, 2012 On tap. Golden yellow color, mildly hazy with all the fine particles suspended in the body. Very nice foamy cream-colored head, leaving great, generous lace. Really nice-looking beer. Very nice, enjoyable spiced aroma. Cardamom, lemon peel, other complex herbal tastes.. Hint of juniper berries, I think. Nice lightly-spiced light bitter taste. Way too drinkable for a 9% beer, i could easily (a drink a whole bottle of this on my own if I desired. Drier texture, amazing aftertaste. Very drinkable, it feels medium-bodied. Light carbonation, very smooth. Dangerously tasty beer.
Draft. Pours yellow with a small white head, a bit of lacing, and some carbonation. Aroma has a bunch of chai tea. Taste is light with some sweetness on the finish and a bunch of chai flavor. Cool
Opaque gold. The Chai is dominant on the nose. Full bodied and a touch too sweet. The chai is present again, but this also shows sweet banana flavors and drinks much like a tripel. Very interesting.
Certainly interesting... Agreed on chai, juniper berries and banana. Really pungent and, honestly, kind of soapy.
Tap at Coles. Lots of apricot sweet up front. Some juniper through the middle. Good lacing with small head, a tangerine colour with light body in the mouth.

Bottled 2009, 3 years old at this point. Wow - ramps leaves, impressive. The ale pours golden orange somewhat clear in color with a white head. The aroma brings some rye at first and then citrus tangy notes. Tastes like a tangy ale, not quite a saison since it lacks that typical yeasty flavor, with a pleasant light tart ending and some of the rye malts in the background.

What the hell am I drinking!?!  I havent come across anything like it!  I like beer, I like chai tea, and I like the marriage of these two elements.  Those spice notes are outrageously good!  Those chai and lemon notes on the nose and tongue!  Where is the alcohol?  I know its there, but so delicately hidden.  I just have to give it up to Dogfish Head for creating beers that no one else has the balls to even try.

Pours a cloudy gold with white head. Aroma is very sweet notes of caramel and fruit. Very fizzy, medium light body. The taste is sweet and spicy. At first it is tangy with notes of spice, it gets sweeter as you go and the black chai becomes more prevelant towards the end.

Bottle. Pours a hazy orange, copper color with a white head that dissipates quickly. Aroma is orange citrus, chai, and other spices. Taste is belgian yeast, wheat, cardamom, and chai. Full bodied. Very good.

Draft at the Khyber. Poured a pleasant golden amber with a frothy head. Smells like a spicy orange chai. Very pleasant aromas but not quite what you would expect from a beer. Taste has a few deeper spicier notes. Cardamom. Root flavors. Sweet but not overly so. Surprising acidic backbone. Bit fizzy on the tongue. Does not easily fit into a beer category.

Pours a hazy golden yellow. Aroma is very complex. Strong spicy smell I can't exactly place. Taste is multi-layered and complex. Definitely Belgian influenced from the presence of esters. But spicy and a bit tart as well. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle 750 ml
Aroma soft fresh , pleasant nose, gentle compilation. Mild alcohol hint , juniper berry. 8-
 Appearance  hazed amber with large foamy white top. Good lace created.
Flavor and Palate : medium full bodied, soft textured. malty bottom, touch of alcohol. Clean bitterness sitting on walls. Alcohol well hidden. Neat brew.

Pours golden with a small layer of white head. Amazing, vibrant smell, bit of a soda-like texture to it. Chi tea, some cinnamon, bits of fruit, and desert breadieness. Taste is sweet, bit of bitterness and bite like a golden ale, but has some more of the subtle flavors like tea and black licorice. Complex and unique, pretty good.

Draft at Crunchys, East Lansing. Hazy medium orange-brown body, thin to medium cream head. Herbal, spicy nose with clove, coriander, and cardamom backed by brown sugar and toasty sweetness. Body sweet, like Dubble Bubble bubblegum with clove and sugars, in addition to tannic tea leaves, coriander, and nutty tea leaves. Alcohol heat is noticeable too. This reminded me of a funky pumpkin beer, and my enjoyment flagged after a few ounces.

On tap at Ashleys Ann Arbor.  Pours a hazy gold with a white head.  Strong, very nice aroma of cloves, coriander, and ginger.  Flavor is similarly spiced, ginger, coriander, cloves, other herbs.  Very tasty, just slightly light on complexity.
On tap at the grad for beer week. Aroma is of coriander, Juniper berries, banana. Lots going on. The flavor reflects the lemon leaves also. Very tasty! Quite fizzy with a nice head.

0.75 L bottle kindly shared by GrOve. Virtually no head. Body is light brown and hazed by millions of microfloaties. Cardamom, ginger and cinnamon hit the nose at first, offset by a whiff of gingerbread, mint and green leaves. Light in the mouth for such a big beer. Taste is dryish light malty with a spiced up tea-like and herbal character. Dry spicy finish. One of its kind. I like it!

Pours a hazed orange color with a bit white head.  As with most sahteas, a very herbal aroma.  Lots of juniper and maybe some ginger notes.  Lots of spices as well, mostly coriander and cardamom.  A slight tartness is also noticeable.  Strangely, there is a strong flavor of banana to go along with the juniper and spice character.  Lightly tart and lemony, which is sort of interesting.  Actually pretty enjoyable.

From notes: Poured hazy straw-to-orange color, with a small white head.  Mild aromas of spice and tea.  Slight thickness to the body, with a mild depth.  Taste was reminiscent of honey up front, with the tea appearing in the finish.

Really smells of tea, together with caramel and banana. Pours a nice golden yellow beer, with a white head (floaters). Tastes of spices (cardamom and cinamon). Body is thin and dry. It was a very light to drink, exciting.
Colored a little like orange kool-aid. Bright and creamy. Spiced and would be good with Indian food.

Hardly any head. Coppery body made hazy by a whole fleet of floaties. Sugary chai (ie: cinnamon, cardamom, and other spices) aroma with pumpkin spice notes. Dry-sweet cinnamon cardamom and herbs taste with mealy sugary notes. Mid-bodied. Mild mouthfeel. Dryish herbal mineraly honey aftertaste with spicy licorice notes. Nice, but too dense and artificial. (0.75l bottle shared by gr0ve.)
Orange gold pour. Aroma is dried fruits, yeast and spices. Flavor is fruit berries, tea, pepper, and spices. Mellow and sweet.

Pours a golden orange. Tons of smell coming off! Warm chai, clove, cinnamon and citrus. Taste like candied orange with cinnamon, cardamon, clove, black tea, fresh giner and sweet malts. Thick mouth feel, like warm honey. This is a interesting beer gone perfectly right! what a wonderful marriage of spices!

Bottle. The pour was a hazy orange with a slight brown tint and had a thin (less than 1 finger) white frothy head that dissipated quickly, which in turn do not produce any significant lacing.

The aroma was of a light bread malt and a sweet doughy yeast with hints of nutmeg, coriander, brown sugar, cinnamon, clove, banana, a bit of citrus and a infusion of tea.

The taste was malty and very sweet with hints of nutmeg, brown sugar and banana early on with the flavor getting a getting a bit spicier with notes of coriander, clove, a mild black tea presence and a nice dose of citrus (lemon I believe) at the end. The flavor lasted only a short while after the swallow with a nice smooth spicy finish.

Mouthfeel was just about medium in body and rather creamy in texture with a very mild carbonation.

Overall a very sweet tasting brew with a lot of the fall spices, very reminiscent of a Pumpkin Ale.

Pours a cloudy orange, with a moderate eggshell head.  Intense aroma of juniper and chai/pumpkin spices, a little banana, and some yeasty lager aroma beneath.  Flavor is equally intense, heavy on tea and lemon, as well as clove and juniper.  Lots of tea in the flavor, from start to finish.  The alcohol is very well-concealed until it shows up in the finish.  Very flavorful and delicious in small portions.

Bottle.  Cloudy golden beer, lots of sediment, with a very thin frothy white head.  Sweet aroma, lots of spice, similar to a pumpkin beer.  Taste is also sweet with lots of spice once again, coriander especially.  Not a ton of flavor overall.  A little bit of spice/sweetness on the finish, but not much.  Medium bodied, soft carbonation.  Pretty drinkable for 9% abv, and a little boring to me.

D: Enbär och gran - frisk
S: Mycket avbalanserad smak, den "värsta" enbären lite tillbakadragen.
Positiv frisk och inte tvålig

UPDATED: JAN 13, 2012 Cloudy carrot orange. Lemon and orange peel aroma. Taste of brown sugar, pumpkin (sorta) and more sweetness than I would expect: nutmeg. Banana pudding, carrot cake. Some black Earl Grey tea, naturally. Smooth, juicy feel. Sweeter than expected, but a spicy, nutty brew. Very well done for the holidays.

Very spicy nose, Tonsof sediment in the pint glass . Not attractive. The juniper comes through, as well as the tea.   Definately worth a taste, highly recommend trying it if get the chance. I like it.

Bottle.

Pours hazy orange, with a small off-white head. The aroma and taste was interesting. Forest, spices, juniper and malt. Also some notes of tea. Refreshing and with a rather light body.

UPDATED: FEB 8, 2012 A- cloudy floaties orange amber   No head little lacing.  

S - quiet apple cider, bananas, chai spices cinnamon nutmeg, with a  light citrus (tangerine?)

M - lightly carbed with a creamy but syrupy mf. Overall a nice feel, almost wants to be warmed up.

T- spiced cider on the nose, with subtle orange notes and chai spiced tea. Vanilla.

O - interesting specialty beer. Nice combination of citrus and spiced chai tea.  Good beginning and middle. AtToo sweet malty yeast  ending lingers.

6-

Very spicy nose, Looks like someone backwashed in the glass. Not attractive. Tastes quite spicy, slightly sweet, Quite rich. A very excellent beer, highly recommend trying it if get the chance. I like it,  a lot.
Great smell.  Smells of hops and chai tea.  Im not really feeling the taste of this.  It sounded really good, but I just dont like it much.  Really yeasty and... just odd.

Bottle: &nbsp Cloudy orangish amber, very thick, thin white head, spritzy, little lacing. &nbsp Spicy nose, a 

little like pine or spruce. &nbsp Spicy on the tongue, mild sweetness. &nbsp Comes across as either pine or spruce. 

&nbsp Reminds me of Alaskan Winter but with more spice, less hoppiness (this one isnt that hoppy btw), and with a 

little thicker body. &nbsp Interesting style. &nbsp A bit more body then others I have had. &nbsp Somewhat dry on the 

exit. &nbsp Not half bad, and certainly a change up from a lot of the standard brews out there. &nbsp Bet this would 

pair well with a salad with vinegrette and walnuts. &nbsp Crazy!

Bottle I think picked up at Wine and Cheese a little under a year ago. Clear copper color with a small white head. HUGE aroma of banana, clove and a little apricot. Pretty mild flavor with more influence from the weizen yeast. The tea is lurking in the background and finish. Absolutely no hint of the 9 ABV. Unique.
Tap.  Smelled of Banana and spice.  Complex flavoring with a very interesting blend of malts, yeast and spices.  Very different and good overall.

Poured from a 750ml bottle from 2011 into a tulip glass.

A: A clear pale orange with a lot of carbonation bubbles floating up. A thin tan creamy head sits on top.

S: Fruity, yeasty, herbal, honey, chai tea, and juniper. Very good smell here.

T: Sweet. Fruity foretaste into a chai tea flavor with a fruity finish. Honey is hinted throughout, interesting flavor.

M: Medium carbonation with a rather thick creamy mouth feel.

O: I like this, I wouldnt drink it on occasion, but thats why its only offered in 750ml bottles, its definitely made for certain occasions. A sweet beer, but not overly sweet, with a nice complex flavor.

Served poured out of the bottle into a pint glass. Has a nice sort of dark orangey color, smells delicious with hints of the juniper berries, floral notes, and a surprise spice. Taste is amazing with the juniper berries and spice really coming together well and a hint of banana. Overal just a terrific tasty beer that can be enjoyed by even the biggest beer novice.

2009 Vintage. 750ml into a DFH signature glass.

A - Cloudy light brown/dark yellow body with a small white head and some light edging. The last pour was especially murky, Not sure what is floating in the beer, but its certainly suspended and sticking around.

S - Tea and sweet earthy spices. I can get a bit of the juniper berries and some light alcohol. Malts and hops are just not present. 

T - Mostly just the spices and tea. The aftertaste is a bit earthy and yeasty. The mouth feel is medium but lacking carbonation.

O - I really enjoyed this beer when it was fresh, IMO the flavor profile is just too delicate and aging does it no favors. Still a cool representation of a crazy style. Like most people, this is the sahti I have tried.

Bomber. Orange pour with a white head that did not stick around very long. Tons of sediment throughout.  Almost mead like in appearance, texture and taste. Sweeter than I usually like but it is a very unique and well done brew.

Hazy orange, head diminishes to nothing quickly.
Smells sweet and like a potent herbal tea. Quite unique concoction of smells that are hard to dissect. But the wiezen character is obvious with a clove aspect 
Tastes sweet, little hop bitterness, cardamon pods, medicinal, peppermint.
Feels slick and sticky but cooling and medicinal with a long duration.
Conceptually interesting and I think well executed for what it is.  Enjoyable.
From a tap,orange in color,white head,clove, caramel, herbs, hazy, mediim body, oily feel, lively, medium sweetness, not bad.
750ml bomber.  Dark golden pour with a quickly dissipated head.  Nose is fruity with some good saison type funk.  Taste of citrus (mainly grapefruit) and chai spices.  Enjoyable.

750 bottle bought in Michigan and taken to the StlHops Pinball event.  This poured hazy kind of golden and smelled quite nice.  It was chai tea and spices.  The flavor also included those along with yeast and pumpkin and other spices.  This is very unique and was also delightful.

(draft at Another Pint 7/31/11). Light gold/orange color with light cloudiness. Medium off white head. Moderate ginger and pepper aroma, with light sweetness and very light berry and earthiness. Flavor of the same, with light sugary sweetness and light clove. Avg duration. Light dry finish. Slick texture. Moderate carbonation. Spare lacing.

Something about this beer just completely turned me off. It started off well enough with a nice hazy orange/light red-brown color. Minimal head, very syrup-like pouring out of the bottle.

Smelled of forest-herbs and trees. Medicinal tone to it, and strange acrid bitterness. Taste was similar, but very medicinal and almost milky-spruce flavored with a sweet honey/burnt tea layer as well. Not a good combination on my palate.

The mouthfeel reminded me of carbonated milkan egg-cream or something unnatural. This was tiring on the palate and seemed to inject the terrible flavor directly into my nervous system...

I poured 90% of a 750mL bottle down the drain. Ill try again next year to be sure I wasnt on mescaline or something, because Ive liked almost everything else from DFH that Ive ever had.

Pours a hazy orange, with a small off-white head.  Aroma is heavy with ginger, spices, coriander, and pepper.  Full bodied flavor with fruits, sweet malts, and gets very spicy in the finish, which is very dry and bitter, with a long duration.  Overall very nice, balanced, and different.

Courtesy or Armed.  Drank this one at our friend Vinnies house on the night of Hurricane Irene, August 2011.  Very tasty beer, on the light side, refreshing and you can definitely sense the juniper berries and tea ingredients.

Draft at the Davis Beer Shoppe. First impressions was it was a classic, complex brew right up Dogfish Heads book. Aroma was sweet, with a clove/tea mix in there. Thick on the palate. Complex but I enjoyed it.

Dreaft at beernutz.  Orange gold color.  Aroma of lemon and coriander and orange.  Med lite sweetness.  Med lite bodied.   Slick texture.  Ave carbonation.  Has a spicy peppery finish.  Quite unique.  Complex.

Bottle, pours and looks like iced tea.  Spicy aroma, and has interesting taste of many different spices, mild tea flavor, but sweet.  Complexities in this brew for sure.  The alcohol does give you a warming effect.  Another different brew from Dogfish Head, they are all worth a try.

pours a hazy orange, pinkish tint, with a decent white head, some retention and lacing. light herbs and light spicyness - well balanced indeed, light bananas, citrus, hint of cereal sweetness. lively carbonation, medium body. very nice.
750 ml. bottle.  Looks like iced tea with a white head.  Sweet, refreshing, and has a little kick.

An aroma of chai tea. flavor the tea with banana and clove much like a good enough tripel. berries and perfume of berry works its way into the flavor pattern. putty sweet body and some malt works its way into the lengthy diminishing finish. not bad at all and not worth the price to try it $12.99 the 25oz bottle. looks like tea in the glass.
Draft at Kickbacks. Hazy amber pour with a thin white head. Scent is lightly tart, some berries and spices. Taste is citrus, berries and banana.

Pours a cloudy light orange with a big but short lived white head.The aroma is of sweet tea with notes of fruit.The taste was of tea, fruit, with a tinge of alcohol and spices.The body was full with slight sweet aftertaste.Overall a complex and tasty brew.

750ml bottle courtesy of CaptainCougar.  Awesome spice aroma, very reminiscent of a pumpkin beer with the cinnamon.  Thick orange, with an oily head that laces the sides of the glass.  Very complex, lots of spicy flavor, but they meld together quite well.  One of my favorite DFH beers, I really enjoy this one.  Hides the alcohol perfectly.  Very unique.  Smooth cinnamon chai tones, with a hint of weizen yeast.  Clove tea.  No hops that I can discern.  Works.  Awesome.
Bottle, pours a nice bright yellow. Taste is quite good, it was very yeasty, with a really nice hint of chai tea in finish, Pretty good offering. Smell is nice too
yup, tastes like chai. reminds me of christmas too for some reason. the alcohol gets to be a bit much as it warms up. but its interesting nonetheless.
Pours cloudy orange with spiced herbal notes.  It drinks sweet with notes of herbs, malt and yeast.  It has a long sweet finish, a little to much to my liking.  Overall a nice beer.

I was surprised that I liked this so much. It pours golden orange with a small white head. The aroma is full of herbs and spices, but not too overpowering. Just enough to make it interesting. The flavor is sweet and yeasty with lots of fruit. Apples, lemon, orange, banana, coriander, clove come to mind. Its kind of like a sweet and spicier German hefeweizen. Doesnt overwhelm the palate.

Bottle brought from the Dogfish Head brewery by my step brother. Pours a golden colour with an initial white head that disapears rather quickly. Aroma is overwhelmingly sweet. smells like bubblegum, and like dough, like banana pancakes or waffles. Reminds me of Belgian yeast as well, but smells very German style. Taste is sweet, and a little tangy on the tongue. Spicy, and banana. Almost a little bit of pepper too. Pretty cool.

Bottle pours a hazy orangish/ golden with a medium white head. Coriander and cardamom dominate the nose and mesh well with juniper, notes of citrus and black tea evident. Taste similar to aroma flavors are bright and refreshing. Generally not a fan of a lot of the ingredients used here but this one is drinkable.

12/30/10 at az wine

Hazy golden orange with a soft white head which disappears quickly. 

Big ol chai tea nose not sure if that is a good thing but it is definitely strange there are also aromas of yeast, orange floral tea, soap, juniper, eucalyptus and faint vanilla.

The flavor matches the aroma. Again, weird. Definite chai with a yeasty finish and lingering vanilla tea. A sourness grows as it sits to warm. The palate is not too sweet but, combined with the oddity (or oddi-tea?) I wouldnt be able to drink much more than a few ounces. Curious. 8/4/6/3/12/

I also got this one in my "new dad" basket. This is an interesting concept, a couple of proto-beer styles mixed together in a way that I guess we can start to expect more of from DFH.

I have to say I really enjoy this one as well... itll never be my favorite, but I do like something new and weird every once in a while. I have to admit that Id never heard of Sahti before today, Id definitely be interested in trying some of it in its purest form at some point.

The aroma is out of this world, and absolutely perfect and exactly what I expected when I picked up the bottle! The only 10 Ive ever given for any category.

This is like a wonderful "Belgian Beer Gingersnap" if you were to take that cookie and dip it in a sweetened Rooibos tea. Im liking the chai-ness of it, the clove, coriander and cinnamon aroma and taste; the rustic aspect of the sahti is drawing me in as well - I love learning about where beer came from way back.

The clodded cloudiness reminds me that there is real biology going on and I like that a lot! If I saw this on tap and I was in the mood for a nice chill desert - Id choose this over cake or ice-cream any day.

bottle - Pours a cloudy orange with no real head. Aroma is big with the juniper berries, spices, tea, pepper. Taste is spicy sweet with the lingering spices. Palate is a little oily/creaminess, like salad dressing, that really coats the mouth and lingers. Overall, this is a unique beer that Im enjoying quite a bit!
Poured nice with a small head smelled of belgian yeast tea and sweet tasted about the same good beer with good chai aftertaste

Draught @ Iron Monkey, Jersey City, NJ
Pours hazy orange with no head. Aroma has notes of malt, dried fruits, apricot and spices. Taste is medium sweet and light bitter. Body is full, texture is oily, carbonation is flat.

Bomber, shared. Poured into snifter dark orange with rusty hints, small white head. Clean appearance, no lacing. Nose is black and red teas, some juniper and spices I couldnt place just yet. A few sips yields mostly red tea, slight biscuity notes, cinnamon and ginger. Very different. Like the Theobroma, Im glad I tried this, but doubt Ill buy it again.

A very unique beer.  Medium dark amber color with a thin head that fades fairly quickly.  Aroma/taste reminds me of bananas and chai tea.  Very complex beer that hides the alcohol well. Hard to believe that it is 9% abv when feels more like 7% abv.  Very crisp and tasty.  I wish it could be added to the year round portfolio.  One of my favorite beers!!

Tap at Maggies Attic. Pours a hazy amber with a thin white head. Black tea, coriander, spicy citrus in the aroma with an odd herbal note, too. Smooth crisp malt taste with lots of herbal tea and spices as well as a honey fruitiness. Lots of flavors going on, would like if it focused on just a couple.
Very "gran cruish" with a plethora of flavors.  Overflavored with withfruits, spices, sugars, etc.  Delish!

UPDATED: JUN 29, 2011 Draft @ Coalhouse Pizza in Stamford, CT. Served in a mason jar, this is one of those intricate brews that seems to have a different taste with every sip. The tea, spices, wheat, malt and hop flavors all blend together nicely and the hop/malt/wheat body gives this beer a complex, medium body. The ABV is hidden well in this beer as well.
A very unique beer. I have never had a herbal mint tea beer before.. not bad for a summer drink. 9% ???, hard to believe, seems like 2%.

1" head-rosy/off white and quick to disperse. hint of trippel sweetness on the aroma. definite r.s. but very light and refreshing brew lifted by the herbal juniper tea infusion.9%? super long lasting minty tea finish without being astringent or offensive. the malt buttresses this whole experience-solid
could taste and smell the chai right off the bat. some sweetness towards the end possibly from the juniper. really crisp and clean, a decent beer, fun to try once in a while
Aroma of clove and cinnamon.  Pours bright Orange with a big bubbly head.  Tastes of nutmeg, cream and juniper.  Tasty but just as big as I was expecting.

Lovely odd duck this is. Pours with a small, off white head that mostly fades, and a little lace. Color is a hazy medium amber. Not all that much to look at. Aroma is exquisite - spices, yeast, malt, fruit, herbs, in an exotic blend that is beguiling. So I drank some. Flavors not as intriguing as the nose, but still pretty good. Reminds me of a good saison. Maybe just a touch too sweet. Anyway, most of the aroma characteristics but muted. Body is decent, perhaps could use a little more carbonation; however, still good. Finish is short to medium in length with a little booziness.

Pours light amber with a thin white head.  Aroma includes berries, caramel. floral hops and some honey.  Taste is light but overwhelming in flavor.  Was unsure about it at first but definitely a great, original brew.
Cardamom, coriander, barley malt on the nose. Hazy amber, thin head. Overripe orange and banana, kind of funky. Alcohol noticeable, but

Appearance: clear, bright orange  with no discernable head or lacing.  Aroma: chai, banana, clove, caraway.   Taste: honeyed sweetness over rye heat, with black chai, banana, bubblegum and clove.   Finish: sweet and syrupy going on dry and hot.   Notes:  On tap at the DFH Aleworks in Gaithersburg; poured into a snifter. An incredibly interesting beer with a lot of disparate elements coming together in pursuit of a complex, tasty whole.  Pretty good.  I liked the spicy heat of the rye, which complemented the sweet and syrupy texture.  The tea-ish notes were undeniable, and the weizen yeast imparted some great clove and banana notes to complement the tea elements.

9/16/2009
Pours a slightly cloudy deep golden color with a smallish bubbly white head that fades to a cap. Smells of pepper, cold tea, nutmeg, and sweet malt, spicy aroma to be sure. Slight phenolic in the nose as well but not to dominating. Taste is a bit sweet with a spicy rye and pepper tone to it. Reminds me a lot of a Saison only with a spicy sweetness. The phenolic is in the taste as well, but subsides a bit as it warms. Taste is a little on the sweet side but I think that plays real well with the spices. Light carbonation, medium body, slick almost creamy mouthfeel. 9% alcohol is barely noticeable. This is yet another DFH extreme brew and I really enjoyed this one. Thanks Sam for always pushing the boundaries.

pours a golden orange, not much of a head. aroma is very spicy upfront, lots to take in, taste is no different, mostly i taste clove, but other spices come through too. cannot even notice the alcohol. good job dfh as always.

Purchased overpriced at City Cellars in Cincinnati, Ohio - Alright, you have some chai tea and pour cheap malt liquor into it, youll get this taste. Some folks might rank this one high because it is different, but thats not my view,.
Pours a cloudy amber with thin off-white head. Aroma of chai tea, fruit and yeast. Mildly sweet taste of the tea and fruit, with a bit of malt character. Interesting.
UPDATED: MAY 10, 2011 Very strong scent to this light golden beer, has a spicy scent with fruit notes. Very unique and pleasing taste, very smooth finish for 9%.

750 mL bottle from premier Gourmet in Buffalo, tasted with Chris and Dan. Served in a goblet. Pours hazy amber with a small white head. The head fades to a bare cover and leaves a small amount of lace. The aroma has huge clove, along with juniper, ginger and hints of lemon, apple and yeast. The flavour is moderately sweet with citrus, juniper and earthy chai. There is a crisp minerality and juniper notes in the finish. On the palate, it is medium-full in body with a smooth, creamy texture and soft carbonation. Overall, this is an unusual beer with intense clove up front, a nice minerality in the middle and juniper notes towards the finish. An interesting taste experience, but not one of their best beers. 2011-04-16

Great brew. Pours a dark burnt umber with a thin whitish head. Earthy, spicy and berries in the nose. The mouth is also a bity spicy balanced againt some fresh citrus and a bit of juniper. Decetn brew.

On draught at Aces & Ales. Dense orangish gold color with a lingering white head and lace of fine bubbles. Medium body with full mouthfeel. Malty sweetness with fruity character (apricot). Flavor balance onthe sweet side, not quite like traditional Finnish Sahti with a dry Rye finish. Late alcohol presence.

Bomber from Premier. Great spicey and fresh aroma. 
Looks- Unfiltered look, has a half inch of soapy head and is lacey.Carbonation bubbles.
Smooth mouthfeel, very drinkable.
Juniper worked, also positive that not noticeably gingery. Carmel, pecans, cola, carob.

draft last year... I think at Dash In - This unusual brew has a spicy aroma that to me brings to mind nutmeg and maybe sage and cinnamon.  I see from the description above that none of those spices are actually in it.  hah... oh well.  The flavor has strong spices.  I wouldnt call it subtle.  Theres also sweet rye along with caramel and slight bitterness.  Unusual.  Good.

UPDATED: APR 4, 2011 Pours a nice darker yellow color. Aroma is sweet of the tea, weizen yeast and juniper berry. Taste plays out the same way - weizen up front, then a long finish from the tea and the berry. Palate is medium, very long finish. Covers alcohol well.  This is an interesting beer, and once given the description I am able to like it better. A once in a while beer, growing on me as I go through the 22 oz bottle.  - After note - once this beer warms up a bit, the edge of the sweetness on the aftertaste disappears. The beer really grew on me.

poured from a 750ml bottle receieved a case form one of my groomsmen for the wedding present.  This beer is best if chilled and then opened and let it sit out and come down to room temp.  The beer is a light amber color.  smell of chia tea.  Taste is the same.  Great beer!!!

Poured a hazy orange color with a thin off-white head that faded quickly.  Very fruity aroma with berries and mint.  Tea notes as well.  Taste is fruity with tea at first, with some minty notes.  Taste transitions into a lemon and grassy flavor with oranges and coriander.  The finish is a little bit dry but the alcohol is well hidden.  Overall very interesting and enjoyable, the balance is very good for the number of different flavors.
Bottle pours deep orange/gold with a white head. Aroma shows notes of juniper, black tea, clove, ginger and some rye spiciness.  Flavor shows the same with additional notes of coriander.

750 ml bottle. Pours a deep amber/gold with a thin white head. Receding head dos not produce much lace. Aroma of multiple spices, yeast and gin. Smooth palate made interesting by lively carbonation. Quite drinkable. I shared my bottle w/ the Mrs, but could have drank it myself. Flavor is a great mix of weizen yeast, spice, fruit and juniper. There is a tea like flavor too. I guess its chai. Im not sure I dont drink chai tea. Delicious, interesting brew.

orange/tan colour w/ lots of sediment
nose is huge; ginger bread, cloves, banana bread
full body and very fizzy and sugary
very sweet. lots of chai tea flavour and now that ive tasted it i can smell chai as well. after i got used to chai i could taste a lot more ginger and cloves. nice but i couldnt drink a lot of it.

UPDATED: NOV 5, 2013 Ridiculously easy drinking for a 9% beer.  Mildly sweet with a good bit of tea flavor some sugar, and very smooth.  Honestly, I know tea beer sounds bad, but its awesome.  Tough for me to describe, not much nose,but very tasty.
scoring from notes, do not have enough data to write in a description

Bottled. Pours a soft, hazy golden color with a small white head. Nose is banana bread, lemons, spices and, yes, black tea. Similar flavors are found in the taste. Sort of reminds me of a witbier. Definitely a odd beer.

Hazy orange body, white head. Yeast floaters. Aroma has cookie dough, alcohol, cinnamon, cardamon and juniper berries. Flavour has sweet malt butter with cardamon, some bread. Oily, thick and smooth, perfect palate.
WTF is a traditional ale, this certainly isnt traditional. As far as a sahti goes it is pretty crappy not one of my favorites form DFH.

Such an interesting beer. Dont forget to drink it because youll be so preoccupied with smelling it. I love the spices in its aroma and taste. All shine through with grace and balance. I love the use of the weizen yeast which gives it even more uniqueness. Fantastic beer.

Holy chai tea.  Smells like a fresh brewed cup of black chai tea.  Neat.  Chai taste is not too subtle either... but I kinda like it.  It goes well with the strong, dark malts in this beer.  There is a little bitterness to keep the sweetness from getting too out of control.  Tastes even better when aged.  Malts get more complex, chair mellows out, and an almost acidic, sour flavor emerges.  Very unique brew, as a DFH should be.

Dirty gold colored beer with a decent, white head. Faint aromas of coriander, lemons, and wheat. The taste is truly unique. Berry lemonade mixed with fresh coriander peel. The black tea hints are noticeable and a welcome touch to a delicious brew. Extremely refreshing and easy to drink. It is also very hard to describe. I need to buy another bottle for further review. Another quality brew from Dogfish.

Bottle/750ml - Pours a darkish golden amber in color with a small, foamy bright white head that settled to a bubbly ring around the top of the beer.  Aroma is full if spices... coriander and the lemon grass come out most strongly.  Flavor is slightly sweet, quite citrusy and the spices again dominate the profile.  The juniper berries lay in the background, but a gin drinker can pick those out anywhere.  The tea does not come through until the finish and then it provides a slighly tannic balance to the lingering sweetness.  Unusual, but pretty good and very drinkable.

Bottle; Pour is golden with a modest white head. Retention is modest - lacing is nearly nonexistent. Aromas - Cardamom and Tea leaves on the nose. So very spicy, this one. Caramon dominates, naturally. Coriander takes a back seat and the lemon note is very subdued. I wouldnt call the "spicing subtle" in any way, shape, or form unless its simply subtle for this particular style of beer. I couldnt say.  It honestly took me about 20 minutes and suddenly I noticed the Yeasty/Weizen note. The Juniper berries are present, as well as honey. There is a slight dry feeling on the finish of this brew and a tingling sensation on the tongue. I really enjoyed the experience here, but I highly doubt Ill pick this one up again.

golden brown with large white head.  nose of some yeast esters and a touch of spice.  moderate carbonation for the style.  little bitterness before some esters and a touch of spice.  medium residual sweetness resulting in a rather drinkable brew, though the overall flavor is somewhat peculiar and not overwhelmingly inviting

Aroma: clover, clove, ginger, orangy citrus, and pepper, a little winey; Appearance: frothy head on pour, but quickly dissipates, hazy yellow, maybe even slightly creamy, unfiltered sedimentation, looks just fine to me; Taste: awesome boquet, very complex, can taste everything that I could smell, clove dominates, sweet, I have to laugh at my aroma and taste impressions given that nothing I smelled or tasted is even mentioned on the bottles description of ingredients, to each his own I guess; Palate: sweet, spicy, and orangy, aftertaste very similar to an orange pekot (sp?) tea, Overall: very unique and very tasty, glad to have had the experience drinking it, but wouldnt need to keep one on hand, too unique for me to be able to pair it up with food, I look forward to trying more of Dogfish Heads "ancient ale" series!
Orange-yellow pour with a white head. Aroma is light of spice, orange and lemon. Flavor is also light with a very smooth and crisp taste. Alcohol is nearly completely hidden.

Pours a murky orange into the glass with a light foam head that leaves no retention nor lacing of which to speak.  The nose is of definitive juniper berry, herbal teas, some yeast and citrus, possibly a bit of wheat... super complex.  The flavors are nice, well-integrated, and indeed reserved for such a large ABV. I get the herbal tea, yeast (in the form of banana), pie spices, some melon, and some Candi Sugars.  The alcohol is hinted only in the spice finish, and even then, not entirely noticeable.  The mouthfeel is slick and full-bodied.  It goes down very well on a winters evening, with many complexities coming together in a smooth pull.

Bottle: Poured a cloudy orange color ale with a large foamy head with good retention and some lacing. Aroma of sweet malt with notes of juniper and Chai tea is very pleasant. Taste is also dominated by aroma of juniper and nice fresh wheat malt with notes sweet fruity ester. Body is quite full with a nice texture and some good carbonation and no apparent alcohol. A lot better then I had expected based on previous experiment from this brewer.

Bomber. Cloudy orange with a nice fluffy soft head. Aroma of nutmeg, clove, cinnamon, yeast and chai. The chai spicy flavor really comes through. A little sourness, too. Mouthfeel is soft fluffy carbonation.

Bomber. Cloudy ass orange-yellow color with lace. Big spicy nosejuniper, ginger, clove, slightly sour rye grain, sour fruits. Sweet-and-sour flavor, very fruity, eastery yeast, banana or melon, lemon. Unusual. Sweet blends well with the sourness. Sooth, full body, soft fizziness. Cant taste the alcohol. Good, but wouldnt want too much.

The story on this beer - as usual w/ Dogfish Head - writes a pretty big check for the tasting experience to cash.  Surprisingly, it more than lives up to the legendary feel of the backstory.  The flavor is incredible.  The spice notes sneak up on you...the chai flavors seemed to rush over me in the finish.  If anything, I almost wanted a more vibrant mouthfeel, but Im not sure if that would have worked with the sublime flavor.  I do recommend this highly.

Pours a hazy medium gold with a 3 finger, creamy yellow-off white head that has decent retention, but leaves no lacing. Aroma is pumpkin pie spice, black tea, sage, earthy fruit notes and earthy wood. Flavor is more pie spice, sage, sweet citrus, sweet hay, toast, pale caramel, tea, sweet grass and light citrus. Palate is medium bodied, between syrupy and slick on entry, and sticky on the finish. Definitely a nice brew, sort of a Christmasy spice feel to it even though it may not be intended to be a Christmas beer.

Bottle at home ... golden amber ... thin white lacing ... herbal  light spice ... int of cardamon .. little banana esters ... little cinnamon nose ... light fizzz ... big spice front ... again a banana wheat flavour ... nice
It has a citrusy, orange look, smells like a  banana.Sweet. Apparently this is what chai and juniper berries smell like? I dig it.

I guess Im not good enough for anything DFH.  Cloudy pale yellah. Slight tea aroma. Weird off initial flavor. almost made me gag. THen it grows on you, terribly interesting. Plastic and artificailly non sense for beer. Very unique and offensive. Difficult at times. Not bitter but not acceptable, yes a special kindah beer. Rather shockingly different. Iced tea and lager.
