text:
Large bottle. Poured into Duvel tulip. 

Large slightly off-white head diminishes quickly to very minimal amount of traces of foam atop the beer. 

Beautiful deep golden/dark straw color. Slightly cloudy. A handful of sediment clusters floating around. Nice and slow effervescence. 

Vinous and spice aromas seem most prominent. Chai tea aroma, with scents of black tea and cardamom as well as ginger. Hints of clove, black pepper, and cinnamon (in order of most robust) on nose. Yeasty scents. 

Aroma base like a Bavarian hefe (eg, Franziskaner) though this is a much more complex ale due to the additional ingredients. Also robust aroma of spices covers up any banana like scents.

Taste is as if took a Franziskaner and mixed chai tea concentrate in as well as increasing the abv. Quite deliciously complex.  

All the aromas listed above are noticeable in taste. 

Fruity esters, ginger, and subtle semi-citrusy notes on front palate. 

Bavarian hefe taste mid palate. 

Strong presence of chai tea spices on back of palate and especially on finish. 

Overall, an enjoyable beer to sip a glass of, though perhaps a bit too uniquely robust to finish off entire large bottle at one go. 

Smooth mouth feel. Wet finish. Spice bite.
Pours a pale gold and a small fizzy white head. Nose is berries, nutmeg, chai, coriander and spices. Palate is light and easy to drink.
I always keep at least two bottles of this beer in my fridge. Overall excellent beer worth trying and sharing. This beer will excite your taste buds like few new beers can do. Awesome beer.

Pours a murky pumpkin juice coloration with small frothy head.  Smells of straight up chai which is very pleasant.  Taste is of plenty of chai tea, some lemon, honey, apple cider, pepper, bannana, and yeast.  Mouthfeel is crisp and refreshng, very drinkable for 9%.  Delicious I liked better than i thought, and i thought id like.

On tap at the Dogfish Alehouse this past summer.

A: Pours a light apricot-yellow with a nice amount of white lacing. 

S: Lots of spicing throughout--ginger, nutmeg, a bit a cinnamon. A little bit of herbal tea. Some gin notes.

T: The gin-type notes become more prevalent and there is a honey-like sweetness underlying the above-mentioned spices.

M: Medium-bodied, slightly dry, and well-carbonated.

D: Quite drinkable. This is definitely one of the more drinkable Dogfish "experimental" beers.

Serving type: on-tap

Reviewed on: 10-28-2009
Interesting and decent.  Gold, slight haze, draft at McGregors in a chalice, nice.  Minimal head.  Very spicy cider nose.  Palate is cinnamon alcohol is well-hidden, very nice.

On tap at McGregors. Pours a hazy yellow color with a small off-white head,. Has a sweetish malty spicy aroma with lots of cinnamon. Sweetish malty spicy flavor with cinnamon and hints of coriander. Has a sweet malty spicy finish.
On tap at Maduro in Madison, poured into a snifte,r pours a clear golden with a creamy head, the aroma has nices notes of spices and frut, the flavor is fruity with a dryness that follows.

750mL bottle purchased at Barks Beer Cave in Plattsburgh, NY.  Lots of smokey, herbal, juniper berry notes in the aroma.  There is also a significant yeasty banana ester aroma here, too.  Not a huge fan of the nose.  This is like a transparent golden snowglobe.  Lots of suspended floaties present here.  Pretty small and quickly dissipating white head.  Starts sweet, sugary, and a bit cloying.  Some honey notes in the middle before there is some floral juniper berry flavors to finish.  Sticky and cloying with underlying estery yeast flavors.

The brew pours an orange color with very little head. The nose is like a white ale with loads of citrus, honey, and spice. On the palate the spice comes through along with a very nice citrus flavor. This beer is quite good and very drinkable.

750 ml bottle. Poured golden wirh nice white head. Aroma of sweet spicy citrus.  Flavor is way sweeter then I like my tea and there isnt mych tea either. Its a slightly spicer midas touch maybe. Nice and drinkable but with the list of interesting ingredients on the bottle I wish it was a more interesting beer

750mL bottle, pours hazy golden orange with a small white head. Aroma of juniper berries, coriander, lemon, very earthy and black tea. Flavour of juniper berries, tea, quite fruity, a little sweet, quite earthy.

Bottle pours clear, light amber with small, fizzy, off-white head.  Aroma of light hops.  Predominant flavors of peach, cherry, vanilla, and cotton candy.  Very unique and what you come to expect from Dogfish Head.  Enjoyable.
750mL bottle.  Everything you would expect from combining Chai tea and Dogfish Head beer.  Goes down easy, even though it is fairly heavy (9% ABV).  Another great creation from Dogfish!
Tap at fiddlers hearth.   aroma of sweet, burnt, doughy toast.  additional layor of chai.   taste is perfume and melons.   weird trash and paint thinner aftertaste.  did not like.

Sampled at Fall Gerryfest 2010. Pours a great colour, golden with an orange tint. The aroma is fantastic, lots of that chai tea spice along with some fruitiness. The taste is also quite good, if a little on the sweet side. The chai aromas really dont add any heavy cloying taste, you get the smell of it without much of the taste. The high ABV is well hidden, and the balance is quite good. Its a surprisingly great beer!

I have to admit, I was a little disappointed that I didnt taste as much tea considering its half the beers name. That said, the flavor is wonderful. Mildly hopped and with a touch of acid sourness, Sahtea is very much like a saison with a hint of juniper and woody, grassy spice notes, with a muted sweetness.

Wonderful, just wonderful. Dogfish Head is a true testament to honest business and the long lost American Dream, and this beer is just more proof. Im a huge tea and chai drinker, almost as much as a beer lover, so I was i especially excited for this one. I poured it in a snifter, and it wasnt as dark as I thought it would have been, but I could smell the cardamom and coriander almost immediately. The flavor was full-bodied yet subdued, rich and complex and very balanced. The juniper came out notably. Overall, a stellar beer in which the many flavors coexist splendidly. A brilliant concoction, and a credit to its craft brewery name.

Draft at Flying Saucer Fall Beer Festival. Pours a murky orange. Aroma of lemon grass and spice. Medium bodied with a somewhat soft carbonation and nice earthy mouthfeel. Flavor of pale wheat malt, tea, and juniper berry with a good amount of residual sweetness. Good

Clear orange marmalade is her name, though marmalade certainly isnt her game. A minuscule head of white bubbles fade into a thin collar while generous swirls produce nothing spectacular in the way of lace. On the other hand, my generous swirls produce a nose I can smell from my chair, glass not in hand. Sweet and spiced and already tickling my nose, I immediately cup glass in-hand and revel in all her glorious aromatic splendor. Just as promised, black chai abounds, mingling with honeycomb, green bamboo, cucumber, bay leaves, honeydew, and flower petals caressed by a spring breeze. Not all is sweet, as wave after wave of mischievous spices make themselves known: cinnamon sticks, black chair, and freshly picked green chili peppers. Invigorating; I am more than ready to partake of her orange marmalade depths. Instantly mouthcoating, her heavy body coats my lips with exotic honeys kissed with honeydew and clings to the inside of my cheeks. Each quaff lingers with black chai and chili pepper, their spicy heat bleeding into the next quaff, and the next, and so forth. Im not complaining though, not in the least. Her sticky current of honey and marmalade is complimented by slivers of cucumber. In the instance of Sahtea, her nose transfers beautifully to her palate as I revel in all that she has to offer.


A limited release, I should have brought home more as she is a rare bird. Good luck finding any more bottles anywhere; I know I havent had any more luck. In the meantime, I have the most delicious memories of me and my Dogfish Sahtea.

aroma is obviously crazy, bursting with vanilla, cardamom, maple syrup, and tea. bright citrus and banana aromas are also there, and start to dominate as it warms
pours hazy orange with fine white head.
flavor is sweet and spicy, like chai tea with milk and honey.
medium-bodied with spicy sweet finish and very well-hidden alcohol.

Appearance is a pale orange that cannot be seen through with a thin white head. Aroma is of citrus, cloves, spices and tea. All of these aromas come through quite well in the taste. This is what I would imagine a German Hefeweizen would grow up to be. This is a very good beer from one of the best brewers in the world. Well done Dogfish Head.

Bottle.  Pours hazy orange with a lasting white head.  Aroma is of yeast, spices, sweet malt, fruit and berries with hints of tea.  Flavors are similar.  Full, smooth body.  Very interesting, complex, delicious brew.

750 ml bottle - pours a hazy yellow / orange color with no head and very sligth carbonation.  Aroma is heavy with floral notes - juniper, fruit, and a bit of honey.  Flavor is exceptional.  Full bodied with a sweet start and a smooth, floral finish.  Touch of herbs, coriander, cinnamon pepper the tongue with a beautiful mix of varying flavors.  Finishes sweet and lingers with a wonderful flavor that just ends this beer perfectly.  An amazing beer and a new favorite of mine.  A shame its so expensive and hard to find - however, next time I see it, Im picking up a six-pack :-)

650ml bottle pours yellow with average head.  Very fragrent, aromas of flowers and perfume, some aromas of sweet yeast and herbs present.  Taste sweet of citrus and spice, citrus like lemon and orange, spices like coriander and tea.  Deffinatly taste the chi tea with a full body and hides alcohol very well.  Very complex and the aroma is excellent

7/24/09.  750mL bottle from 2009.  Clear honey gold with small white head, fair retention.  Juniper up front with some light perfumey notes.  Flavor adds more honey and earth, with a semi-dry light earthy bitterness peaking at a 3, tinge of alcohol noted.  Light to moderate carbonation, medium-full body.  Not bad.

text: 750ml bottle.  Pours a blond amber color with a thin, whitish one-finger head.   Aroma is spicey, with banana and clove with a faint hint of juniper.  The flavor is extremely complex with a strong chai presence, a bit of fruitiness from the juniper, and a lot of herbal spices (many layers).  Medium body, moderate carbonation.

Bottled 2010.  Huge spicy aroma, just loaded with cloves and coriander, juniper, vanilla, rye, honey, sweet overripe banana - heavy Hefeweizen yeast in huurrr.  Has some of the fruity muddle of my failed HB experiment using re-hydrated fruit in the Mosherian style.  Fizzy head on a dark golden body, very noisy and short-lived.  Tastes a bit like my HB experiement, as well - alcohol is warming but not too harsh, but theres a scratchiness on the throat that is impossible to escape, as well as a light numbing on the sides.  The sucker is bone dry but the alcohol itself, in combination with the esters, lends an initial appearance of sweetness.  Full body with the smack of liqueur.  Faint peach with lots of dust and light grass clippings.  Juniper with very harsh spicing and slick, rollicking vanilla-tinged malt.  Yeah, that about sums it up.

Pours a cloudy yellow with a white head. Aroma has notes of citrus and spices. You can easily pick up on the Chai tea spices. The flavor is sweet and for some reason the sweetness is the dominant flavor for me. The spices are there just not in the forefront. I really like the ancient ales series from Dogfish Head. This is another good entry.

A beer very different from anything I have ever had. Shared this bottle with a friend. A very murky yellow color with lots of bubbles and a one finger head. The aroma is very interesting with a sweet herbal motif. Also a lemon curd and pickled ginger like you get with sushi. esters and a bit of the juniper bitter comes through as well. I got a good amount of juniper and tea on the taste backed up by the hardy grain. THe teture was sharp with a pretty high carbonation but it went down easy. Big marks for originality.

Bottle.  Aroma: Citrus, cloves, array of spices. Appearance: golden, hazy, white head.  Taste: medium sweetness, slightly spicy. Palate: light bodied, thin, lively.  Served for my 3rd course at my changing of the seasons food/beer pairing.  Went excellent with our curry chicken salad.

Absolutely delicious. Packed with flavor from the rye and the chai, the lemongrass comes through and the German Hefeweissen yeast really comes through. Everything works well together and melts in your mouth.
Draft.  Medium gold pour, thin white head.  Sweet malt, herbal, spice, fruity esters and banana.  Nice silky smooth mouthfeel.  Too sweet for me, glad I only got a half pint.

Hazy deep golden pour thin ring of white head ... lots of aroma ... aroma of rye, juniper berries and herbal tea ... taste of juniper berries mostly and some herbal tea flavor a peppery/rye bite to it  ..... an herbal and sweet brew with a light bitter dry finish .... a unique and tasty brew

Notes.

Very interesting flavor profile, with the juniper berries and tea sticking out most.  Spicy, sticky, and overly sweet.  A tasty beer that would make a nice bottle to share with 6 or 7 friends, but I had to spend a few hours drinking one bottle alone.

Hazy light brown colour with tiny white head and lots of sediment floating in the glass. Cardamon, cinnamon, juniper, yeast and malt in aroma. Spices, malt, bread, some sweetness, mild hoppiness. Very nice carbonation and stil rich palate.

Tap @ Parkway. Hazy dark gold pour with an off-white head leaving a moderate lace. Multiple flavors assault you at the first pull: spices, vegetables, fruits, maybe even meats? Definitely some tea in there. Too much going on for me and not balanced. I much prefer the Midas Touch or Theobroma from DFH.
pours a peachy golden color with no head or lacing.  Aroma is citric and spicy.  Taste is strong with yeast and herbs.  Botanicle finish.

Drinking this one after a long day of running and wandering around annapolis with the girl.  Sharing this one with her and drinking it from my special tasting glass.  Pours a yellowish brown color with an off white head.  Smells of bananas, spice, carbonation, and tea!  Taste is also of bananas, bit of sweetness, and some carbonation.  Not overly carbonated which would have been a turn off for me.  There is some subtle notes of tea in the taste as well as a spicy taste.

Bottled (thanks Thomassova4). Golden colour, small white head. Aroma is juniper, spices, herbs, some tea, mild maltyness. Quite pleasant. Flavour is herbs, spices and malts. Extremely pleasantly balanced. Nice thing.

Bottled 750ml
Hazy orange color, small white head, some lace. Aroma of banana, coriander, juniper and maybe black tea. Spicey and sweet. Honey, coriander, cinnamon, tea, banana, rose water. Interesting, spicey mix of German wheat beer and Belgian strong ale. Good beer nothing to do with sahti.

I sampled this beer from a 750 ml bottle shared with elnadeau & gstoad.

I liked this beer a lot. As they mention on the label, its quaffable, however, there are lots of nice flavors going on. Well done

Bottle from craft beer store. Golden pour with orange hue. Nose of clove, 

banana and orange peel. Tasted mild pine, lemon and a peppery finish. It was good.

Pours a cloudy light golden color.  Aroma is very fresh.  Scents include: ginger, juniper, cloves, and coriander.  Flavor is nice and crisp and includes anise, juniper, yeast, wheat, and clove.  Has a nice and crisp Belgium finish.

Tap at Churchkey.  Golden color, large white head.  Aroma of jasmine, dandelion.  Taste has summer fruit and spice, very much a mixture of a lot of competing tastes and aroma.  Interesting but jumbled.

750 ml bottle. From Boston, MA, USA. Courtesy of Brandman.
Hazy light brown colour with tiny white head and lots of sediment floating in the glass. Cardamon, cinnamon, juniper, yeast and malt in aroma.
Spices, malt, bread, some sweetness, mild hoppiness.
Very nice carbonation and stil rich palate.

Dogfish Head
Sahtea
Pours golden with a medium white head. Very pleasing aroma of gardenias, coriander, mild juniper and bazooka Joe bubble gum. Darn nice. Flavor is spicy sweet with coriander, and lemony tea with a floral aftertaste with some bananas. Complex, very interesting and very good. I will buy more soon.

On tap at Coles.  Really pale, with little head.  Big spicy aroma which is quite appealing, but would perhaps be overwhelming if youre not into that sort of thing.  The flavour is the spice once again, along with German wheat yeast.  The flavour is big and distinctive, and lingers a long time.  Very interesting, this one.

Pours a cloudy orange with a thin head.  Aroma is spicy like the chai thats in it.  Hints of cinnamon, clove and a small trace of nutmeg.  Flavor is comprised of all the spices above will still being very refreshing.  Palate seemed to be concentrated with black tea.  Very Delicious.

Smells great. Lots of juniper, a hint of ginger as well. Beautiful thick-looking head quickly disintegrates. Orange-yellow. The flavor is rich, juniper and thick tea. A thick malty rye finish.  Really interesting, but very good. Cinnamon of chai tea but no milkiness.  Maybe some bananas too. This is truly excellent as an adventure beer; Id actually buy this as a six-pack if it was cheaper. Its price is the only downside to this beer.

Draft at Obriens. Cloudy orange with fair amount of white whispy head, nice patterns in the foam. Nose is bombastic, full of spices and floral accents, honey, sage and  ginger are prominent. Flavor loses a bit of momentum, big spices and herbs up front, solid backbone of bready malt, light citrus hop flavors, finishes sweet and spiced like a winter ale. Medium body and carbonation, slick texture. A big, bad spiced herbal ale that has a very experimental feel, good in smaller amounts, probably not big on return visits.

Excellent golden, frothy appearance with good carbonation and full body.  Tastes much like hoegaarden but more refined with subtle notes of chai spices and a little acidic/tinny lemon sting at the end.  Overall, a great beer with a lot of character, but much closer to a traditional beer than I expected.  As with most DFH beers, the high abv is well concealed.

Bottle shared by joshuahfl. Pours hazy dark gold with a foamy 2 finger off-white head. Nice gin aroma. Medium body with mild carbonation. Very smooth. Tea aspect is muted. So much juniper its almost ginger. Very tasty, and the heat is also muted. Good.
Pours a hazy gold color with a medium off-white head.  Aroma is like a Hefeweizen, light banana, clove, and spice.  Taste is much the same - cinnamon, yeastiness, and spice.
Pours cloudy yellow with a rich off-white head and a juniper aroma. The flavor is sweet and fruity with a tea background. Sure doesnt taste like 9% - goes down easy.
Poured hazy golden yellow, bananna, clove, vanilla, little yeasty, little honey.

Pours a cloudy gold into the glass with a white head that disappears quickly.  Aroma is somewhat sweet with a ginger like aroma that I would imagine is from the cardamon or lemon grass and then a bit of bubble gum.  Flavor has a nice spiciness to it that turns to a dry finish, possibly from the astringency of the tea.  Nice beer, deceptively alcoholic.

On tap at Sergios.  Hazy orange pour with a nice white head that leaves some solid lace.  The aroma is very pleasing--spiced with a gread doughy gingerbread character going on.  The flavor is similar, but more spiced and less doughy/gingerbready malt character.  The flavor is a bit lighter on the whole than the aroma.  The alcohol is very well hidden.  It is perfectly smooth on the palate--full bodied with low tingly carbonation.  Overall: this is an interesting beer and would be great on a cool Fall evening or in the early winter months.

Bottle from Kenny Road Market. Surprisingly good; much better than I had anticipated. Aroma is honestly not that great; I didnt get much spice, just a honey sweetness, while not bad, was a little disappointing. Luckily, the flavor was quite good; everything I hoped for in the aroma came through on the tongue. The cinnamon and tea flavor from the chai was fun. Bitter and sweet.

My first Sahti and Ill admit, its pretty damn good.  pours a hazy golden color with medium off-white head that fades quickly.  Aroma is like a tripel and a hefeweizen.  There is an abundance of cinnamon (clove) and lemon and Belgian yeast.  The taste is mirrors the aroma, tons of clove and light notes of banana with Belgian spice.  Moderate carbonation and indistinguishable alcohol.  Well done DFH!

Cloudy orange pour with a nice looking white head.  Aroma is banana, clove, vanilla, bubblegum, very slight citrus.  Definitely picking up on the hefe yeast.    Could have gone for more carbonation on the palate.  Nice, smooth feel with the chai spice showing up on the tongue accompanied by vanilla and banana.  I like this one.  And the fact that its 9%... sign me up!

I really like chai tea, but I am not 100% sold that it pairs well with beer.  This proto beer has a missing ingredient, so the tea was a substitute.  I hope the ingredient is found.  Definitely worth a taste if you are into meads, and their Midas Touch proto beer.

Bottle from Park Lane. Aroma is strongly Chai. Surprisingly authentic chai. Barely even a whif of beer. Hops are noticeably missing from aroma. Appearance is amber with a nice white head. Taste is strongly chai with a hint of juniper on the back end and a bit of a burn in the very back of my throat. The spices really come through. Overall a great beer. This is unlike any beer Ive ever had and I would definitely purchase this again.

750 ml bottle from Holiday Wine Cellar ($13.49).  Pours an orange-amber color with two fingers of white-ish head (looks a lot like an IPA, actually).  Aroma actually smells like chai -- a little milky with Indian chai spices (cardamom, clove, cinnamon, nutmeg).  Also a nice forest-y aroma of juniper.  Flavor is also (kind of surprisingly) very chai-like -- tastes of milky black tea and tangy spice.  The weizen yeast is also notable with a banana and slightly bubblegum flavor.  Nice spicy finish.  Glad this DFH brew has finally made it to California.  I was surprised by just how much this smells and tastes like chai (one of my favorite drinks, especially when I was in India).  The DFH heads brew another truly unique one -- this really expands what "beer" can be.  (314, 356)
Golden Hazy, with lots of tiny bubbles. Low to no head. Aroma is banana (candy like), plums. Taste is bitter, butterscotch and caramel. Medium body. OK, but not great in my own opinion.

Orangy yellow cloudy pour with a foamy white head.  Subtle spice and leafy aromas, a little tart on the onset - but a nice full flavor ... interesting spice and definitely some lemon grass.  Very good and uniquely flavored and refresging brew - enjoyed while making my own on a hot Sunday in August
In short: This golden beer with white head has the aroma and flavor of Chai tea. Very interesting.

Bottle.  Pour is a cloudy orange amber, with ample bubbles and a nice thin white foam that laces the glass.  Aroma is full of spice, sweet juniper berry, and bittersweet cinnamon and clove.  Taste matches the aroma, early on like drinking watery potpourri, but not unpleasant, then turning to a full-on berry fest, before mellowing to a smooth, sweet malty finish.  Certainly one of the more interesting, unique brews Ive tried in some time.  Like a saison meeting a barley wine...  Nice.

Draft at Toad in the Hole. Translucent gold with low fine head. Incredible sweet spicy fruitcake nose with slight citrus poking through. Flavor starts a little funky and yeasty; unusual volatiles play against clean malty foundation.     Alcohol is very apparent, yet strangely unobtrusive; phenolics are a little overbearing in the burps but it never veers into full-on burning plastic, and everything else lays in nicely.

Bottle from South Bay Drugs: Created a thick pillow of foamy head while the liquid was a sparkling golden blonde hue with a little tint of haze.  As for the nose, a vibrant and lively scent of spices and fruit that earn this ale a perfect score in the aroma. Some of the ingredients I was able to sniff out where banana, clove, mint, black tea, juniper berries, and lemon zest. The flavor is fully supported by the aroma and holds the very same elements. Has plenty of fruit flavor similar to banana, and then has dashes of spice that add coriander on top of the clove, juniper berries, and lemon zest. The black tea flavors hide deep in the background, but the overall flavors and yeast used make a tasty and rewarding beer.

Quite a tea-like beer, with lots of chai aromas and flavors.  Instead of the milky smoothness you would get from a traditional chai, however, there are hops and alcohol, not bad substitutes in my book.  You would have to really like beer already to get something worthwhile from this unique brew.  Fortunately, there are plenty of familiar notes to get you through the tasting!

750 ml bottle shared by Tmoney99.  Pours a hazy lighter amber/dark golden color with a medium sized white head.  The aroma is an interesting herbal spicy blend that shows the influence of the Indian black tea.  Hints of yeast and doughy malts.  The flavor has the yeast, banana and doughy malt of a hefe blended with some juniper, spices, herbal notes and hints of citrus.  Medium-full bodied with a smooth feel.  We had this along side a traditional Sahti and found this to be an interesting spin on the style.  Well worth the try.

Pours big white head with tight bubbles. Fairly carbonated. Golden body. Spicy aroma. Slightly phenolic. Flavors of banana and clove. Definitely taste the weizen yeast properties. This could pass for a Christmas offering from any brewery easily.

Bomber. pours a nice hazy golden color with a little red.  aroma is citrus and sweet notes of sweet tea, spices.  taste: taste the tea right off the bat, then some spice and sweetness making taste like an apple cider, great carbonation, and then a nice dry finish. cool beer.
Pours hazy orangish gold color with thin white head. Aromas of juniper and corriander. Sweet and fruity with lots of spices and a little bready. Medium body with average carbonation.
Good brew.  Pours cloudy orange.  Aroma is rather doughy, with hints of banana.  Taste has a bit of spice to it.  Feels nice in the mouth with good carbonation.  Hot finish.

UPDATED: JUL 25, 2010 Bottled shared with good people.  Poured a hazy golden with a decent head.  Aroma was of chai, some mango and maybe some lemon zest.  Flavors follow suit with a good punch of cinnamon, coriander and allspice.
Excellent full mouthfeel with a smooth finish.  A little sweet for my taste but very unique and tasty.  This is one to share, good stuff.

Pours a translucent dijon musturd color.  Has little head and lace.  Aroma is of bubblegum, cloves, black tea, lemon and bannana yeast with rye bread malt.  The taste has heavy sweetness, no bitterness and a light sourness.  Medium body, oily texture, lively carbonation and bubblegum, black tea finish.

Sampled on 7/19/2010. This traditional ale pours a cloudy orange gold color from a 750ml bottle. Small to medium sized white foamy head. The aroma is fruity and sweet, spicy, ginger, tea, juniper berries and lemongrass. A medium to full bodied traditional ale. The malts are fruity and sweet, lots of tea. The hops are herbal and spicy. There is a lot of flavors going on here, tea, ginger, cardamom, coriander and juniper berries.  A very different beer, even if it is not entirely like beer. Good carbonation. Another one of those strange, weird and totally different beers that Dogfish head seems to come up with on a regular basis.  Mouthfeel is full. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is sweet and spicy.

(bottle - 750 ml) Hazy gold pour with a thin white head. Huge aroma of chai tea, black tea, cinnamon and cardamom. Big cardamom and tea flavor at the start with some light coriander and cinnamon coming up behind it. Very well balanced throughout with all the flavors definitely detectable. Finishes clean and sweet with a lot of spices and tea. Very nicely put together.

Bottle pours a lightly hazed yellow golden body with a small vanilla head. Perfumey aroma smells like sandalwood incense, juniper berry, fresh ginger root, and floral and herbal hops. Light medium body is light and airy with a spritzy carbonation that works well. Taste is interesting, to say the least. Juniper berries impart a gin-like astringent bitterness that envelopes the myriad spicy notes into a pleasant melange. Cardomom , ginger, and nutmeg flavors are picked up throughout. Alcohol is not noticed even at 9%. By the end of the bottle, I was very enamored with this ale althoough I have no idea whether DFH has brewed it anywhere close to a traditional sahti. In any event, I would enjoy another one about anytime.

Bottle. Pours a hazy yellow color with a small off-white head,. Has a sweetish malty spicy aroma with hints of coriander. Sweetish malty spicy bready flavor with hints of coriander. Has a sweetish malty spicy finish.

Pours very clear orange. No head. Not the best looking brew. Nose is ginger, tea and white pepper. Very nice nose. Taste is spectacularly balanced tea, ginger, white pepper, coriander, light spices and juniper.

Cloudy yellow orange in color... Aroma of chai tea, citrus, berries and cinnamon... Flavor is honey, cinnamon, chai, berries... Really sweet and light initially, but definitely has a warm alcohol finish on the palate.. Very unique and tasty beer

Pours the color of honey - golden orange.  Head comes on strong then dissipates just as fast. Aroma of honey, cloves, nutmeg, and of course chai tea - maybe hints of spearmint as well. The taste is very much original: one would think that the tea flavor would not work well with the beer flavor, but it does. The juniper berries also add an herbal "gin" note that also mixes well.  Very well balanced, although not something I could have multiples of.   The high alcohol content is hidden well in the spice, honey and malt - almost no bitterness from the hops. Almost makes me want to get into braggot.  Almost.

Bottle. Chai aroma with a hint of hops.  Golden body with thin head.  Flavor is amazing... chai, yeast, coriander and spice... saison like but with dominant vanilla chai aftertaste....  would be great for any season... light and refreshing yet full of flavored spice

(750ml bottle).  Disclaimer: my wife is Indian and I have had lots of home made chai, not the garbage that Starbucks serves.  So I know what Chai tastes like.  Pours orange-amber with a white head.  Aroma smells like chai (cardamom, coriander especially) and tastes like it as well.  Its not overpowering though.  There is a bite from the spices in the finish that I particularly like.  This beer is Fin brilliant!  Dogfish Head has a unique ability to take strong flavors and incorporate them subtly into their beers (Theobroma is a prime example).  I think this beer is great and will be picking up more.

Bizzottle.  Pours a bright gleaming orangish-yellow topped with thin white head that settles just around the glass.  Nose is spice laden with white pepper, ginger, coriander, etc.  Ive smelled that aroma before...many times, its not unique as people claim, it smells like a beer with a shit load of spices in it, just like every other beer with a shit ton of spices in it...you know, the kind that starts to smell like melting Styrofoam after a while.  Do i get Chai in there?  Who knows, i dont drink that shit much.  Flavors do have a more pronounced chai character for sure...some solid sweetness, but balanced with the spicey chai character..the body is thick and welcoming, but it doesnt come across as syrupy at all, at least not to me.  I get the Rye character...its not too forward, but its definitely there and it definitely is complimenting with the Chai.  This is certainly not my style, but I really like it regardless...it definitely has a christmas thing to it...it would certainly go with some christmas cookies, or better yet, a spicy cigar.

on tap @ brick store pub, decatur, ga.  spiced like a christmas beer and just as strong.  alcohol does not register on sonar.  the spicing is most definitely NOT subtle but it is expertly balanced.  this beer is way too easy to drink, even on a summer day in Georgia.

Big bottle. Amber, off white head. Chai all over the place with this one, though not overly so. Aroma is lots of spices, in addition to to chai, maybe nutmeg, holiday-ish. Taste is more black tea, reminds me of street smells of India. Medium sweetness. Would drink again. Interesting, tasty and different without being gimmicky. Another DFH accomplishment.

Bottle tasting at work. Im a bit surprised this hasnt been placed in the spiced category. A hazy golden pour follows into a small, white head. Nose is a pronounced belgian yeast aroma followed with hints of juniper and chai tea. Palate is light to medium bodied with a creamy texture. In the taste the traditional chai flavors really shine through, expecially in the finish. A slightly sweet, relaxing summer beer best served chilled. Be careful though, it is a beer for a very specific group of drinkers. Lovers of the belgian yeast strains who enjoy chai tea and a light summer beer will really enjoy this... if you dont enjoy those things, you probably wont like this beer. That said, I really enjoyed this beer!

Cloudy golden pour with no head. Interesting aroma of chai tea, fruits and honey. Flavor of honey, chai tea and fruits. The body is light with a liquorous texture and moderate carbonation. Interesting.

One of the most crazy flavored beers I have ever enjoyed! This beer has flavors of berries and and just like the aroma there is a scent of black chai. This beer is truely an example of pushing the beer boundaries!

750ml Bottle.  Pours cloudy golden/brassy with a light 1/2 inch white head.  Strong Intense chai tea aroma with a hint of wheat and other spices, reminds me of Christmas for some reason. at first taste...strong chai tea spices with wheat.  light body with a nice spicy finish that lingers long after.  I enjoyed this a lot, def tastes like nothing i have ever had before. A+ once again to Dogfish Head for making unique tasty brews.

Lucent copper, thin white head,  

Aroma: bright with lots of tropical fruits and spices. 

Taste: all spices, no beer. 

Has some interesting pairing possibilities.

Pours beautifully, and finishes much too sweet. Very much like chai tea. I enjoy chai, but not in a beer. I dont know why I keep trying strange beers, when I simply like beer. Beer of all normal styles. Rarely does an attempt like this please me. Cant blame Dogfish Head for trying though.

I am a big fan of DogFishHeads one-off craft/archeological beer series. I am slowly working my way through a case of Sahtea. Overall I like the brew, but I find the spice to be too reminiscent of Chai tea. As you guessed I am not a fan of chai tea- at least not in my beer. Treat this like the strange brew it is and serve small portions among two or three friends. I recommend chalice, or something with a broad top- there is hardly any head with this beer. I like Jiahu and Theobroma better.

Pours amber with the tiniest amount of haze and a slight amount of small sediment.  White head is on the smaller side and fades quickly.  Lacing is on the low side as well.  Aroma really smells just like chai.  Mouthfeel is creamy, fruity, having hints of the estery characteristics of a Weizen. Sweet, almost no bitter, a little spiciness that lingers on the finish.  Very light and refreshing, I drank this at cellar temp but I could see this served at witbier temps and being really refreshing in the summer.  Good stuff, and truly unique.

Traditional ale?  Not at all sure why ratebeer put this in the traditional ale category.  Interesting, to be sure, and drinkable, and not at all silly.  Often DFH beers are interesting, not drinkable, and silly in hindsight.  Why would I want a beer made by professional chewers chewing and spitting authentic Amerindian blue corn?  This one is a bit confusing, but I would have another.  At the start of the pour the tea in the nose is striking but not unpleasant.  The body is a slightly hazy rich orange with a small white heat, which made me think initially of a Belgian tripel but there was no lacing.  Of course ... its rye, not wheat.  The taste is a little surprising as well, its not a triple yeast, but a German yeast.  The spicing in the tea is quite pleasant and the juniper is not overpowering.  The mouth is full and round, but not thick or syrupy.  It works.  Not sure I would ever want a third, but a second would be ok.
Hazy golden with a fizzy white head.  Sweet malty, caramel, tea, and juniper aroma and taste with a strong chai tea finish.

Bottle at Theis and Mettes. Pours a hazy orange with a diminishing white head. Smells a bit like pumpkin ale with spices. Sweet with aromas of ripe bananas and some nutmeg. Hints of perfume. Ever-so-tiny hints of pepper. Sugary. Medium bodied. Soft carbonation.
Bottle at home - thanks to Sune&Bager. Cloudy yellow - white head. Honey. Spicy. Fruity. Tea. Cardemoms. Light juniper. Wheaty. Peppery.

On tap at the DFH Brewpub.  Pours a golden orange color with a white foam head.  Has an aroma of cinnamon, clover, and pepper.  Some beery flavor mixed int.  Sweet with some spicey notes up front.  Then bitter that smooths out with the maltiness.  Some notes of tea on the finish.

This is yet another awesome beer from DFH.  I tasted this masterpiece both on draft and from a 750ml bottle.  The Sahtea pours a mostly clear dark golden color with a very generous, soft and fluffy white head.  The head leaves an utterly ample, beautiful and attractive amount of lacing around the edges of the glass.  The nose is quite fruity and sweet, with notes of berries, yeast, bread, grass, lemon and oranges.  The flavors are a little on the sweet side, but theyre not overpowering.  Usually I dont care for really sweet-tasting beers, but Sahtea doesnt overdo it.  Dogfish has once again found a nice balance between sweet/fruity and overall balance, flavor and drinkability.  The body is extremely smooth and drinkable.  The flavors are really unique, with mostly sweet and fruity notes, but a bit of malty finish.  I definitely taste some of that tea in the body of flavors.  DFH Sahtea is a uniquely delicious and enjoyable ale!

Pours a hazy orange with a tiny white head. Aroma is strong. Spicy and fruity aromas, cinnamon, pumpkin pie, gingerbread. Taste is some lemon zest, gingerbread and coriander, slight tea taste. Full mouthfeel, Good finish. Not really what I was expecting but the 9% makes you "warm" up to this beer as you drink it.

On tap at Capones. Not overly impressed with this one. Very mild flavors. The only unique taste that stands out is the tea flavor. Otherwise, it tasted like a fairly week wit. Granted, I had this after several strong tasting beers, so my palate may have been destroyed by the time I got to this.

Brown bottle, 1 pint 9 ounces, tasted with Luc Bourbonnière, savoured on November 27 2009; eye: apple, opaque, no effervescence, tinry ring of beige head, average lacing; nose: tea, juniper, light spices, caramel, malt, citrus fruits; mouth: tea, juniper, light spices, caramel, malt, citrus fruits, light floral, light perfumy, average carbonation, medium body, foamy texture; overall: quite good

FRANÇAIS

Bouteille brune, 1 pinte 9 onces, bue avec Luc Bourbonnière, savourée le 27 novembre 2009; il : pomme, opaque, pas deffervescence, petit anneau de mousse beige, dentelle moyenne; nez : thé, genièvre, léger épices, caramel, malt, agrumes; bouche : thé, genièvre, léger épices, caramel, malt, agrumes, léger floral, léger parfumé, carbonatation moyenne, corps moyen, texture mousseuse; en résumé : bien bon

Pours a cloudy Orange with yellow tint and thin streaked head retention. Nose is potent, pumkin pie and brown sugar. Tasting is amazing, has strong tea flavor, yet blending hops and malt balance together. Great carbonation and good flavor.

UPDATED: JUL 27, 2011 Bottle shared at a recent BA/RB tasting...  Poured hazy golden with a white head.  Aroma of cookie/bready malts with loads of herbs, yeasty notes, and fruity characters.  Flavors have a lot more tea characters, especially a chai tea tone.  Spices, citrus, lots of fruit.  Smooth, sweet, almost like fermented juice.

Pours clear medium gold with a small, fleeting white head.
Fruity, spicy aroma.  Not one of my usual beer aromas.
Complex spicy flavor that leaves a little heat on the tongue at the finish.
Interesting beer.

Initial aroma of ginger bread cookies, then huge chai tea... clear golden with sediment, small head... smells of chai tea w some spicing, very interesting... moderately lively, medium full bodied, very flavorful, rye notes, different worth trying...
This stuff literally smells and tastes like gingerbread...absolutely spectacular and the 9%abv will leave you feeling warm inside.
Hazy gold with a small white head. Aroma is of fruit, coriander, citrus,  roots and earth. Taste is of earth, light lemon, herbal.
Hazy straw body. Aroma of chai, tea, floral hops and slight cereal. Flavor is heavy in undiluted tea, chai, cardamom, and some toffee. Sweet finish.
Cloudy golden color with white foamy head and nice lace.  Floral aroma, tea and sweet malt. Nice sweet malt flavor with noticeable floral, spice and citrus fruit. Nice lingering aftertaste.

750 ml bottle. Pours a lightly hazy orange with a small white head. Aroma is very spiced cake, lots of ginger and chai, cardamom, it is very heavily spiced, some sweet rock candy notes. Flavor starts with a sweet iced tea note, again very herbal and sweet, somewhat candylike. Picks up a strong ginger, banana from the weizen yeast, some lemon, the berries really come out. Finishes lightly bitter but mostly just spicy. Medium body with a sharp carbonation. Very interesting, unbeerlike, but highly quaffable and refreshing.
Bomber, Pours hazy straw w/ a bubbly quickly-dissipating head, aromas of yeast, cloves, cardamom, and chai, sweet, yeasty and smooth w/ pumpkin spice @ finish, reminiscent of a good pumpkin beer

Bottle. Amber beer with a whitish head. Vanilla, spice, and tea aroma. Chai and vanilla flavor with tea, spice, and backing juniper. Medium bodied. Vanilla and tea lingers with spice and a light sweetness.

From bottle at a tasting
Appearance : Light peach colored. Tiny head.

Aroma : Very spicy, pumpkin spices. Some Chi tea, ginger

Taste : Lots of spices, ginger, cardamon, chi tea.

Overall : Pretty much all spices. Interesting use of Chi tea. I like Chi tea but not in my beer. This is not for me.

Bottle. Hazy gold pour with a medium, foamy white head. Aroma is strong tea notes, spices, juniper, light pepper, hints of gingerbread and sweet malt. Taste is sweet malts, juniper, ginger, spices, tea leaves, and powdery yeast. Body is strong, dense carbonation and a medium-full overall feel on the tongue. Finishes with more tea notes, juniper, ginger, big spiciness and sweet malts. Interesting beer. Dessert-like at times.
Thanks to my sister for this. Zesty, crisp and fruity. Orange color. Somewhat tea in taste, but its subtle. Im getting more of a light spring beer. Lots of fruit. Nice.

Bottle 75cl. @ home.[ Trade by CaptainCougar ]. Clear light medium orange color with a small, frothy to fizzy, virtually none lacing, fully diminishing, off-white to white head. Aroma is moderate to heavy malty, spicy, cinnamon, moderate hoppy, tea, junipeer, spicy. Flavor is moderate to heavy sweet and moderate bitter with a long duration, spicy, berry - fruity sweet, junipeer, tea. This is not my kind of beer. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20100208]

Ah, another test of DFHs uncommon ability to make ridiculous recipes into drinkable beers. Beer smells like strong Indian chai tea, fruity and spicy with notes of tangerine, pine needles and rose petals. Huh. Its a deep orange-gold color with a white head. Taste is quite sweet, getting cloying into the second half of the glass. Very light bitteress and a slight ginny alcohol burn. Too sweet, too spicy, too much. Maybe a nice one for chai lovers who dislike the taste of beer.

Dogfish Head Brewing Company--Sahtea--Ale brewed with Black Chai Tea and Juniper Berries--2009 25.4 oz. Bottle.  9.00% ABV--10 IBUs?  (4.5 / 5.0)  Sahti--Finnish--Thin white mild lace head.  Cloudy bright orange color.  Floral Juniper Black Chai tea mild hop front.  Zesty crisp mild dry sweet orange fruit rich clean malty tea body.  Clean refreshing zesty dry sweet citrus mild hop pine end.  Unique tasty brew.  Sediment End.  Sampled 7/19/2009.  2 @ $13.99 Each.

better than you might expect..one case where the commercial description is fairly accurate..tastes like a cross between beer and iced tea very drinkable..from the description Id like to try the beer without the tea added if they ever make it

Appearance: Served up a deep, burnt gold body with a thin, white head that, in all probability, wilted in transit to my corner table. 

Smell: Sweet-scented, fruity bouquet, with notes of relatively pale malts slathered in honey, unripe orchard fruits, juniper berries, some subtle rye, and, of course, the generously added dose savory herbs and spices.

Taste: Sweet introduction of smooth honey-minded malts and caramelized sugars. Enter in some juniper berry character along With a myriad of fine flavors from all the added herbs and piquant, peppery spices. Then the sweet honey returns again, now pairing with some herbal qualities to provide a splash of Bärenjäger. Hint of rye. Small touch of peeled bananas. Also fruity undertones suggesting pears and apples. Lingering fruitiness beyond the spicy-sweet finish.

Mouthfeel: Medium-bodied. Medium carbonation. Somewhat sticky, though smooth mouthfeel.

Drinkability: Its indeed interesting and quite enjoyable, a beer that was gone well before I had a chance to really explore all its facets and complexities. So, I ordered a second one!

750 ml bottle into my giant dimpled mug. Well, it smells like Chai tea. Also, bananas, clove. Complex. Pours an orange hue with very little head or lacing and lots of sediment. Sweet with very little bitterness. Nice clove-y aftertaste. Lots of carbonation. Overall, another successful experiment from Dogfish Head. I love this whacked out brewery!
bottle, via trade with beachbum25, golden color with minimal white foam, aroma and flavor have a strong herbal element with a decent balance of chocolate and caramel

Pours a medium amber color with a very slight light white head.  Moderately spiced aroma, but the overall impression is one of sweetness.  The taste follows suit with a mild ginger-like spiciness to it, but the sweetness kind of takes over.  Just ok.
Bottle @ de Molen. Slightly hazy yellow color, short head. Aroma is spicy, cardamon, tea, berries. Slight sweet and bitter taste. Strange stuff.

Well, I certainly had this during the White Horse on Parson Green Belgian Beer Festival, 30 August 2009 but Im not sure whether it was a sample from a bottle that someone kindly brought along or actually at the festival (dont see why it would have been). Very herbal. Lots of juniper. Sweet but tasty. Some late candy floss. Interesting stuff if not entirely to my taste. Didnt really notice the tea.
Bottled. The aroma has tea and juniper. Slightly hazy, yellow coloured beer with a white head. The taste is sweet has tea and juniper again. Bit sticky mouthfeel. Not my cup of tea.

Bottle @ De Molen. A little hazy golden colored beer, with a small off white head. The aroma of fruits like juniper with malts and a little spices. The taste of juniper, some notes of tea, sweet malts. The are some spices like cinnamon. The aftertaste of tea with sweet berries and a little bitter.

750 mL bottle, pours out a clear gold with slight carbonation and a thin ring of small bubbles into a tulip glass. exotic spicy aroma, predominantly chai with few apparent sahti influences, perhaps theyll show up in taste. some sweet creaminess as well.  velvety mouthfeel with some sugar and spice, the cardamom is forward with subtle juniper.  definite wheat yeast characteristics, with lots of fruity (banana) flavors.  full-bodied with a sweet sticky finish. an interesting experiment, certainly, but likely a one-time adventure for me.

Light hazy, yellow colour, tiny off-white head, no lace. Sweet, light bitter, sourish, juniper, cardamom. Sticky mouth feel. Flavourful, easy, balanced.
Tastes cermonial, complex, immortal.  This is truly unique; exactly what youd expect from DFH.
Yellow, orange colored brew. Melon, juniper, fruity tea aroma. Sweet flavored, melon, juniper, some spices.
Pours dirty orange with small yeast particles. Aroma is solid coriander to ginger spiced.  Slight spiced note.  Almost too subtle for my liking.  Slighlt over malted finish.

I actually really like this one. The spicing from the tea is very much evident, but not harsh or overdone and it complements wonderfully the sweet malts. The tea itself has not provided any astringency to the beer, which is a plus. Theres a really wonderful fruitiness that is like what I imagine the offspring of a drunken encounter between a canned mandarin orange and a fresh apricot would taste like. My only real qualm here is that its a little too sweet. Really easy beer to come up with things to write about, though.
This was an awesome experience, tastes more like tea than beer which was definitely different for me. The flavor is very sweet lots of fruit and spices!

Pours hazy orange with particles, very little white head. Aroma is sweet and spiced- honey and herbs. Taste is rich sweet honey with lemon and other strange flavors that are hard to place. Incredibly unique and cool to try. Medium body, smooth carbonation. Its weird but I dig it.

Like a mildly carbonated slightly drier chai tea, in my remarkably limited experience with Sahti this is hardly reminiscent of the style at all. All that said this stuff is pretty gosh darned tasty. Pours with the mildest carbonation and falls completely still in no time. The color is a nice golden. The aroma has lots of chai tea spiciness with some vanilla and floral things, but mostly chai tea. The flavor is basically the same, lots of chai tea, mildly sweet... far less sweet than chai tea but the chai dominates the flavor. There is some mild piney juniper flavor/bitterness as well but this one is pretty much a one trick pony, its a damn nice trick though.
No head. Chai tea. Aroma, flavor, etc: chai tea. Some yeast banana esters make it through but thats about it. More bitterness than chai, nicely dry.

I tried Dogfish Head Sahtea over NYE 2010 in Chicago with my brother. While Dogfish remains my favorite brewery, I did not enjoy this ale at all.

The aroma is sweet and the taste full of Chai (as expected). On their own, I enjoy the flavors, but as a beer was overpowered and unimpressed.

Nothing special about appearance.

The parts were decent, but the overall experience was not good.

11th October 2008. GABF. Pre bottled version which I think tasted a little different to the bottle. This was presented as being made with Finnish rice and ramps leaves as well as all the other ingredients. Cloudy looking beer. Soft smooth palate. A nice touch of junier dominates all the other flavours which are ultimately quite subtle.

Bottled. An golden beer with some sediement floating around under a thin white head. The aroma has notes of ginger and tea. The flavor is sweet with notes of ginger, tea, and juniper berries, leading to a dry spicy finish.

75 cL bottle. Pours hazy orange with small yeast floaties. Aroma is solid coriander to ginger spiced. Sweet coriander and sweet buiscuit spiced flavoured. Dry phenolic and slight spiced note. Smooth caramelish and malty finish. Too spiced for my liking.

In short: A fruity, herbal and spicy bear with a lot of tea.  Original and interesting but not very good.
How: Bottle 750ml.  Consumed relatively fresh about 4 months after purchase.
The look: Almost clear golden body topped by a medium white head with low retention
In long: Nose of sweet fruity dessert, herbs, tea, cheap perfume.  Taste is moderate fruity and has more than the advertised juniper berries (I noted mangos, juniper, apples, some orange), soap, camomile, lots of herbal tea, scented flowers, some coriander.  This is an original brew and the first half of the first glass was fun, but it really got annoying after a while, and finishing my 750ml was a chore.  Fortunately the beer is not very tasty because what it tastes does not do it for me.  This is an original tea brew and it might please some people but it didnt really work for me.  Not my cup of tea, pun intended.

Bottled. Golden coloured. Unclear full of floaties. Dense off white head. Aroma of sweetness, spice, bread, yeast, honey and berries. Flavour of sweetness, spice, fruits, bread and honey. Medium bodied. Sweet and honeyish end.

Bottle.
Clear golden coloured with small floaties and a small white head.
Sweet and fruity aroma of caramel and vanilla with notes of spices.
Sweet flavour of fruits, caramel and vanilla with notes of spices and honey cake.
Sweet finish.

Tried on Beer Quest 2010 with all the guys. This was number 9. Loved this brew. Pours a slightly hazy gold. No read head. Aroma of berries (wild berry) and rye bread. Flavor was the same berries and bread. Well balanced.
Cloudy golden with a loudy golden with a tiny white head. Sweet aroma with fruity and malty notes. Sweet yeasty aroma with fruity and malty notes. Finished sweet.

Bottle. Spare fizzy white head that mostly diminished. Spare display of lacework. Light cloudy golden color. Aroma of mild sweet spice, fruit, citrus, honey almost coriander like notes. Medium bodied with an average carbonation. Moderated sweet flavor with a hint of bitterness and acidic. Lingering spicy and fruity finish.

Bottle 75 cl. Courtesy of madmitch76. Pours a cloudy golden with an off-white head. Extremely spicy, gingery aroma. Solid body, lots of sweet malt and fruit with gingery and peppery accents. Sweet honeyish finish. 030110

(Sample Date: 7/18/2009   Source:Other)   At Immys RB gathering. Ginger, juniper and pumpkin pie spices in aroma. Slightly cloudy light honey straw color with small white head. Light peach pear fruitiness. Quite sweet. Finish is juniper and spices. Medium body and full mouth feel. Finish is pumpkin pie spices and juniper.

pours a cloudy golden color. spicy fruity nose. flavor is similar some pears and spice. was actually really nice would buy a bottle again. really wasnt thinking i would dig this one, but hey i definatly did.
Bottle. Tons of graham and juniper... Reminds me a bit like pumking.  Delicious brew.

(750 ml bottle (2009) from 1828 Vintage House) Pours hazy/cloudy slightly reddish golden. Very slight off-white head effervesces away quickly. Strong, almost sharp aroma of mint, juniper, tea and spice (I think) - interesting but not necessarily appealing, esp. for a beer. Syrupy, smooth, sticky mouthfeel, slightly prickly. Flavor of chai tea - very sweet. Some added elements perhaps of licorice, ginger and other spice. Some sweet caramel maltiness is perhaps the only hint that this is a beer. ABV well-hidden. Its all kind of a bit too much and it fairly quickly fatigues the palate. Alot along the lines of Pangaea and Chateau Jiahu. Maybe Im just getting a little worn out of these similar novelty beers from DFH, but I didnt find this one very drinkable or appealing.

Bottle shared by JoeTheYounger.  Pours cloudy gold with a thin white head.  Aroma is bubblegum, clove, and fresh fruits.  Flavor is sweet and a bit spicy with pears and other fresh fruits.  Medium to full bodied with generous carbonation.

Bottle.  Poured a light orange-golden color with just a fizzle.  
The aroma is wrought with a gaggle of spices -- coriander for sure, but also a hint of green leafiness.  This drinks with a hint of gin, mingled with a definite kitchen-drawer-full of earthy spices.  Different, for sure, but not my cup of tea (pun intended). (#3758, 11/29/2009)

A hazy golden ale with a thin white head. In aroma, pleasant and sweet, with juniper berries, ginger and pineapples. In mouth, a nice sweet candy sugar with fragrant spices, coriander, pineapples, nice warming alcohol, a bit lighter than expected. Bottle tasted Nov. 27, with GRM and friends, bought at Kappys Malden, Oct. 2009.

Bottle. Pours slightly cloudy orange-brown with a very thin head. Light lacing but nice carbonation flowing to the edges of the glass, trailing with a swirl of the glass. Smells of chai spices dominate, especially nutmeg, clove, and cinnamon. A soft fruitiness underneath, somewhere around apricots or peaches. Interesting flavor profile, definitely not sahti-like (no noticeable juniper to my taste). Bubblegummy sweet yeast character with a touch of spiciness and lots of honey tones, some caramel in the finish. On the thick side without much carbonation presence. Another odd one from the dfh guys with a better story than execution. Still enjoyable but a touch too sweet.
awesome beer!!!  could really taste the tea in it.  im inspired to brew something similar.

750 ml bottle.  Pours a cloudy antique gold with a thin white head that disappeared after the first sip and left no lace.  Pleasant aroma of malt, honey, juniper and coriander.  The flavor is quite distinctive and enjoyable with malt, honey, juniper, chai tea, and coriander.  I thought it was interesting that the chai tea was quite noticeable in the flavor yet completely absent from the aroma.  Mouthfeel was a bit odd; almost slick.  Overall, this is a very different beer.  Im not sure it is something I would drink with any regularity, but it was fun to try.

750ml Bottle. As soon as you open this one you can tell its from Dogfish based on the distinct and odd aromatics. Pours a light straw color with no head.  Aroma is spicy with strong tea notes and a bit of rye and lemon grass in the background.  This "beer" has a noticeable sweetness to it that lingers on the palate.  The rye character shows up in the flavor along with some subtle spice notes of junipers, ginger, grass and coriander.  Surprisingly it is fairly well balanced and the palate isnt syrupy or thin.  Ends with a hint of clove, yeast and a touch of caramelized sugar.  Not a beer Id want everyday, but definitely another unique creation from Dogfish.

large bottle.  Pours a great color, golden with an orange tint.  The aroma is fantastic, lots of that chai tea spice along with some fruitiness.  The taste is also quite good, if a little on the sweet side.  The chai aromas really dont add any heavy cloying taste, you get the smell of it without much of the taste.  The high ABV is well hidden, and the balance is quite good.  Its a surprisingly great beer!
( 750ml bottle )  Pours a hazy yellow body with a medium white head.  Aroma of juniper, tea, bay leaves, cardamom, and lemon.  Flavor of tea, caramel malt, juniper, cardamom, and some clove.

Bottle [750ml] shared with the gang at WaterlooWeekend Oct.09 -- c/o HogTownHarry. Pours a slightly hazy orange with a spare diminishing frothy white head. Interesting aroma of honey, light spices, herbs, bready malt, fruit and more -- pretty neat.Flavour of honey, spices & herbs along with fruit and mild tea. Medium bodied. Its good but its a bit too sweet to drink much of, to me anyway.

Thin head of miniscule bubbles.  Decent carbonation but the bubbles fight for life on the surface.  MMMM, nice fruity aroma loaded with pears and white grapes.  A light spicyness also permeates the aroma with some grainyness, lemon and straw.  Lots of herbal and earthy notes.  Color is a very nice golden orange.  Light and crisp flavor that lacks the intensity and volume of the aroma.  Light malts, more white grape, some lemon grass and spices late swallow.  Light alcohol presence.  Finishes spicy and earthy with a bit of lingering honey sweetness.  Actually a pretty good brew.  Very easy drinking and quite plesant.
Pours a nice golden color with a white head. It is cross of a lemon tea taste with a german wheat beer. A little bit on the different side. Good but not dogfish heads best.

THOUGHTS: I never had a traditional sahti or chai tea, but this was very good. Very Dogfishy. Very light for the ABV. Hid alcohol incredibly well. It falls into the same general flavor profile of the other DfH historical beers. Basically no hops. Very deceptive. The most deceptive and easy drinking beer next to Mad Elf. One of the better recent DfH beers. It did get a little cloying at the end.
TECHNICAL: Bottle. Poured a hazy, dark yellow to light orange with beautiful carbonation and a large, yellowish head that kept a decent sheet and left fair to good lacing. The aroma was moderate to heavy, musty, earthy, spicy and fruity yeast, along with spices, tea, fruits, slight mustiness and more and more spices. The initial flavor was sweet and slightly tart; while the finish was sweet and a little more tart with an average duration. There was spices, honey, fruits, flowery juniper, fruit as it warmed, tea, nectar, musty earthiness, caramel, and apricot. It seemed slightly Christmasy, yet lighter. Like a Christmas in July beer. The light to medium body was fairly oily, slightly syrupy and then just a bit dry with rather soft carbonation and a light astringent finish.

Draft at Bavarian Lodge. Cloudy burnished brass color, thin white weizen head. Very spicy, even herbal in nose, yet some pilsener type malt can be found. Taste is pretty heady, I start with impressions of cardamon and crystallized ginger. I get more barley malt in the taste than rye, which seems to be buried among all the other spice flavors. Well appreciated.

Bottle.  Pours a hazy browned orange with a small white head.  Cinnamon, vanilla, tea, spices, cardboard, grain.  Medium bodied, bordering on thick.  Sweet, honey and maple. Warming booze and spices on the finish.
( 750ml bottle thanks to bu11zeye) Pours cloudy yellow with some bubbles. Nose of corn, juniper, chai, anise, and allspice. Taste is honey, sweet, and spices.

UPDATED: JAN 29, 2011 Tap at Bavarian Lodge. Pours bright yellow/orange with foamy white head. Nose and flavors are cloves, wintergreen mint, wild belgian yeast. Has a smooth feel to it and refreshing to say the least.

[2541-20091024] 1pt9.6floz bottle. Fragrant juniper and mild mint aroma. Slightly hazy, light orange brown body with a quick foamy white head. Minty hints but flavour is mostly juniper spruce hops and finishes like a tea. Medium body. Interesting to try.
(c/o HogTownHarry, w/ him, blankboy, GregClow, jerc, tupalev)

750mL bottle. Pours a chunky, hazy golden color with suspended protein aggregates; like an overfed fishbowl; white head with light retention and glistening, fine-bubbled lacing. After the Nogne Dugges Sahti over the weekend, this is a nice return to a beer that actually has a huge juniper presence; the aroma shows lots of juniper, pepper, coriander, and rough-edged sugar notes; by no means a soft presence, this nose is rough and juniper-y and spicy; generous. Lively, chewy presence in the mouth: lots of candy sugar, coriander, and overt sweetness upfront, tempered by plenty of white pepper and a generous helping of juniper and, I think, a hint of that hefeweizen yeast doing its work, causing some bananas and bubble gum esters to show through; quite interesting, slightly rough on the palate (following the nose), just an unabashedly spiced sahti rendition; if theres rye in here, Im not catching it anywhere behind the other stuff. Huge, and definitely on the sweet side. Lasting finish of juniper, rock candy, and belgian esters; nicely toasty at the far end.

Finally got to try this! On tap at a local brewpub. nice and bubbly, a fun mouthfeel. Chai tea in the front and in the aftertaste with bread, honey, and spices in the middle. A very unique beer, to say the least. Would certainly have again.

Pours a slightly hazy amber orange with a thin, ring of fizzy white head.  Unique aroma of lightly sweet caramel, spruce, ginger and juniper with a touch of bready yeast and light fruity esters.  Starts with pretty good fullness and a spritzy carbonation with some sugary pale maltiness and herbal fruity spice balance before a slightly citrusy bittersweet finish.  Pretty true to style, well-balanced and drinkable.
Bottle. Pours cloudy gold/orange, with a small head. Aroma is dominated by spices, but also has some malt and sugar. Flavor is spices, tea, malt, and pumpkin. very interesting and unique.

Pale golden pour.  Quite a thick oily pour with a thin fast-fading white head.  The nose is loaded with nice rye character.  Sweet and spicy with a little bit of cardamom, clove and a fairly chewy maltiness.  Loaded with honeyed malt sweetness.  The palate is sweet and chewy with a lingering stickiness.  Lots of spice and a bit of herbal character.  There is a little bit of a distracting carbonic character that I dont particularly care for.  Spicy and sweet with a lot of nice rye character.  Its a pretty compelling beer, really, but it could certainly be dryer.  I like it though.
An interesting beer.  Had a sample of it at the Ale House in Virginia.  The german yeast really shows through as well as the tea flavors.  The flavor was very well balanced and delicious.

Pours with a one finger white head that fades slowly and leaves some lace. Almost clear pale amber color.  Medium carbonation and medium body.  Sweet spicy nose.  Flavor is a sweet spices, almost like a pumpkin mousse, but if you focus the juniper comes through.  Pricey but worth trying even at $13.00 for a 750ml bottle from Tullys Beer and Wine Wells, Me

Bottle, pours a hazy orange gold beer with a thin off white head. Aroma is super berry fruit.  Flavor is sweet and yeasty, but dominated by the aftertaste of the spice.  Citrus notes and  a very well hidden alcohol finish.  Very unique and cool!  Thanks Sam at DFH

2009-10-24. Lightly hazy golden yellow body with a small off white head. 3+ Aroma is spicey, touch of lemon? light juniper, touch of tea. 7+ Flavour is similar, fruity juniper with mild tea undertones throughout. Average palate is slightly under carbonated. Alcohol is not noticeable. Decent, but not sure I would want more of it. Bottle shared by HogTownHarry

Thanks to eaglefan538 for sharing.  This beer was sweet with a lot of ginger and coriander like spices along with some sweet fruity tea like flavors.  Im not a fan of these spicey type beers, and this was no exception.

Bottle.  Pours hazy orange with gold highlights and a moderate fizzy head that quicklly settles to a small ring of foam.  Aroma is nice, definitely some chai tea right up front, honey, gin, rosemary, citrus peel, caramel, pepper.  I think honey is dominant.  Initially, a sweet honey and vanilla mixes with spicy peppery rye tang, with some caramel, more gin-esque flavors, grass, grain, and lingering chai spices.  Finishes like honey toast dashed with Indian food spices and a subtle earthy hop presence.  Fairly heavy beer, but Im surprised at how slick and oily the beer ends up feeling, especially with a weizen yeast.  Some creaminess, but not much, and its not from abundant filtering either.  The rye tanginess is a bit strong and the beer was overall a little better on tap at GABF, with even stronger spices.  But this is still nice!
WTF!!!!!! Bottle. Looks great. Rich head on dark amber. I drink a lot of tea but I am not sure which is worse the Chai aroma or the taste. Honey seaweed and tea. Horrid!
Bottle thanks to bu11zeye.  The smell is spiced, fruits, sweet, and ok.  The look is cloudy, white head, and golden in color.  The taste is spiced, sweet, and fruits.

The appearance is hazy gold with an average head. The aroma is sweet and funky with a bit of a wild fermentation element. It does have enough malt to make it recognizable as a beer and enough juniper to make it a Sahti but the yeast makes it more like a Belgian style Lambic. I dont get much in the way of tea however. The taste is like the aroma with maybe a bit more of the tea that is not detectable in the aroma. The finish is earthy. The palate is smooth. Overall this is worth a try and definitely one that falls in the "interesting" category.

(bottle ( 750ml ).  shared at October 2009 WaterlooWeekend.  Hazy orange pour, average frothy off-white head.  Interesting aroma - tart green fruit, herbal juniper bitterness, light Belgian golden ale fruity/yeasty character.  Tastes like an aged and softened Westmalle Tripel with a little tart green herbal bitterness - definitely the juniper, mild but affecting.  Syrupy  mouthfeel, somewhat thick-bodied, soft, mildly carbonated, sweet but a bit of a tart finish - really liked it.

A nice light colored beer. Pours with minimal head.  The aroma is quite striking.  It makes me think I am about to take a big swig of pumpkin pie.  I love pumpkin pie, but this is a little off for beer.  Luckily the flavor is really balance and quite different than just about anything else.  Strong attack of chai flavor which warms to a really nice finish, mellow and just a slight taste of juniper, very slight juniper flavor.  Overall a wonderful fall beer to sip while enjoying some College football
Bottled. Poured orangy hazy.  Had a cinnamonny gingerbread aroma. I couldnt really notice the chai. Good but Im not sure if Ill get another one.

Bottle: I really wanted to like this beer, but I think just the idea of it is awesome- the actual final product fell short. Pours a slightly hazy light orange with a golden wispy off white head. Has a pale rye/bready aroma- a bit sweet with some odd strong plasticy phenols. A touch of alcohol and vanilla wafer as well. The spices are hardly noticeable- perhaps a note of Chai and cardamom as it warms. Thick- slightly syrupy moutheel. Lots of honeyish maltose and a mild diacetyl presence as well with apparent plasticy phenols. Theres such a faint Chai note on the back, with more cardamom than anything, but its too brief and mild to balance out the richness of the caramelized rye. Slightly under-attenuated. Im not sure if a Hefeweizen yeast was the way to go here- it came out way to phenolic which may have hindered the spice qualities. I liked the idea of this beer, but it fell short. I think Sam comes up with lots of romantic stories behind his offerings but they often are a let down, especially considering how much work goes into them. An A for marketing, however.

light body, creamy, average carbonation, long finish, definite chai on the nose and aftertaste, but not overpoweringly so.  beautiful color, cloudy gold.  definitely citrusy on the nose as well as the spice.  creamy, yeasty, wheaty sort of feel.  very drinkable for a Dogfish big bottle.  hides its alcohol content well.  enjoyable beer.

"Highly unique" says Jabo. Pour a slightly goppy bright orange. Notes of ginger spice, lavender, coriander, jasmine, citrus, rose water, orange, lemon grass, Just a touch of bitter urinal cake" says Sean L aka lil evil. Very yeasty. Definitely gotta lil bit a tha funk. Really tasty. Unique, complex, a little crazy. Great beer. ............................I think its really artsy fing beer.

Pours a fading off-white head with a particulated, deep golden body.  Aromas and flavors of black tea, citrus, cinnamon, nutmeg.  Tastes like chai tea.  Not very quaffable but very enjoyable to drink.

Bottle shared by either mfielden or Sandstone on BA.  Not sure which one to thank, but they both brought some solid brews, so Ill thank both.  Poured into Bruery tulip glass.  This was pretty solid stuff.  DFH can be a bit hit-or-miss with their "traditional ales," but this one was a hit.  Pours a brilliant golden color with a small, creamy white head.  Aroma is spices, tea, rye, and sweet malt.  Flavor is very nice with tea, sweet pale malt, rye, lemon, juniper, coriander, ginger, and other spices, with a fairly herbal character to it.  They used ramp leaves in this?  That is an interesting ingredient that I never expected to see in a beer.  Oh well, crazy or not, it works.  A little syrupy on the palate with full body and medium-high carbonation.
Bottle: pours a golden amber with a thin white head, aroma of citrus, spices, taste is spicy and somewhat sweet, fairly full mouthfeel.  Decent.
Pours light hazy golden with a foamy white head. Notes of lemon, coriander, dark spruce, and spice. Full bodied with lively carbonation.

bottle thanks to bu11zeye.  poured a cloudy yellow with a white head.  aroma of ginger, jasmine, apple jacks, and cinnamon toast.  flavor was ginger, jasmine, and cinnamon toast.  heavy body with medium carbonation.

Bottle Pours out a hazy gold topped with almost no head. Aroma was of sweet tea, bread, and some fruit. Taste more of the sweetness and spice. This on reminds me of chie tea. This was a gift from my parents thanks.

This is interesting, indeed.  This will be reviewed as an experimental, not as a traditional sahti.  Nose of juniper, butterscotch, and wet bark.  Pour is hazy, dark gold and has a nice smooth texture.  I love the black/chai/tea influence that they have used.  It marries extremely well with the spicy rye and herbal notes.  A wonderfully innovative ode to a truly innovative ancestral brew.  Extra kudos for the use of the river rocks as a semi-traditional technique!  Good job guys!

750ml bottlepours a thin white ring for a head and hazy gold color.  Aroma is herbal/spice, sweet light malt, yeast, butterscotch which turns towards caramel as it warms.  Taste is herbal/spice hops, sugar/sweet light malt, yeast, butterscotch which turns towards caramel as it warms.  Saison like.  Thanks to Joe-jwc215 for sharing.
bottle thanks to bu11zeye.  murky gold with a cream head.nose is berries, ginger roots, earth and lemon.  nice thickness with a flavor matching the nose.

Pours a slightly hazy golden yellow with a fairly thick but not too persistent white head. Aroma, though, is strong and distinctive with a firm overtone of juniper and hints of spices. Flavor is malty and a little sweet with a spicy undertone and more than a hint of tea along with a ribbon of juniper flavor. One might think this would taste terrible, but it doesnt at all - its not just distinctive, its quite enjoyable. Texture is silky smooth and just a little tingly. This beer is weird in the best way.

Brother purchased this bottle at Macs on West Peachtreee. I dont know why he did it, but he did. VERY little head. Translucent orange color. Looks pretty thick to me, in regards to the pour. Nice pungent aroma. Big honey spice aroma. Juniper jumps out like crazy. Pungent honey and juniper aroma. Wow, this beer actually smells pretty nice to me. The juniper contributes the most to the aroma. Wow, big spice/juniper flavor. Nice sweet honey/yeast flavor as well. I must say I am actually impressed with this beer. I am definitely not a tea fan, but I must say that this is fairly good. If there is a "tea" flavor in this beer I wouldnt know because I dislike tea. Well, a fine offering from Dogfish Head; pretty good beer I must say. The reason for the "lower" score is the fact that this is so spiced I couldnt drink the regularly.

UPDATED: OCT 12, 2009 RATING 700!  I have had a very good couple of weeks for beer tasting, having tried a number of 4 point brews recently.  Why not celebrate another centennial rating with another adventurous brew from Dogfish Head?  This one is a fascinating concept, and I read about the brewing of this beer in The New Yorker Magazine, which described how the DH crew were boiling this stuff by dumping red hot rocks into the brew kettle!  Sahtea pours dark gold, and comes at you with an attention-grabbing aroma of floral hops, citrus, yeast, cardomom, and a bit of raw funk too.  The flavor is very interesting - kind of like an extreme wit or a a weird abbey ale.  I noticed malted wheat (altho it may have been rye), lime, and yes, chai-type spices.  A little juniper does come thru also.  Sahtea is complex and flavorful, and the 9% alcohol is well masked.  It is a shame that there seemed to be a touch of sour skank in my bottle, however, the sourness seemed to vanish after I opened it and had it in my refrigerator for a day - very mysterious.  A very interesting brew.  If this is what Finns drank 1200 years ago, then they probably had it pretty good.
Dogfish Head Sahtea pours a cloudy golden with a thin, stubborn head.  Coriander, orange peel, chai, cloves, honey.  Well balanced, very interesting, oddly reminiscent of Bells batch 8,000.

Bottle. Moderate malt aromas of light bread, grain and cereal, flowers for the hops, light barnyard for the yeast, pear, dessert wine, wood, honey and you can definitely smell the tea but Im not too sure about the juniper berries. Head is small, fizzy, white, with no lacing and is fully diminishing. Color is murky amber/tan. Flavor starts lightly sweet and moderately acidic, then finishes moderately sweet and lightly acidic. Palate is medium, oily and has a carbonation between soft and lively. An enjoyable Traditional Ale, but it has a few un-beer like aromas and a weird balance in the flavor.

On tap at Coles Dogfish Tasting: Cloudy golden color beneath a thin white head. Not a big aroma, some herbs and ginger snap cookies. Fruity, candied lemon with some herbal mint flavors also. Lightly sweet.

Draft @ Coles DFH weekend. light yellow/orange pour. Orange, coriander, hefeweizen like aroma. Taste is coriander, hefe features, lemon tartness, spicy. Orange tasting finish. Fuller mouthfeel. Pretty good
Tap @ Coles Dogfish Fest.  Cloudy light orange, white head.  Nose is tea, Christmas cake spices, candied fruits.  Flavor is clove, allspice, orange, a bit of tannin.  Sweet candied orange finish.

Septemberfest. Sample from a bottle shared by me.  Nearly still orange-yellow, some white carbonation.  Aroma is honey, mixed spices, ginger, bubblegum.  Taste is cinnamon, spices, ginger, more bubblegum, carmelized sugar, typical chai pumpkin like notes.
Courtesy of bu11zeye. Hazy light amber color. Big chai tea spice aromas. Spicy sweet chai tea flavors on a pale malt base. Chai beer.
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: Nice light golden color with a smallish of-white head. Definite Chai tea aromas, with clove, cinnamon, honey and hint of juniper. Light pale malt and ginger in the flavors. A backdrop of spice and honey. It seems somewhat simple but the more I think about it the balance and blend are really good, so the appearance of simple. This could have easily been a spice and sugary mess. Some rye seems to work its way into the flavors. I like it.

Bottle thanks to bu11zeye. Been looking forward to this one. Hazy orange glowing pour. Aroma is tea leaves, cinnamon, clove, quite spicy Flavor is tea, sweet, caramel, vanilla beans, and some herbal notes. Would go good with some whitefish or chicken.
